description:
A regular lunch spot for me. While the ready made multi item cafeteria style lunch (think Panda Express) is good, what I love is their cook to order dishes. In particular the fish with corn sauce and mapo tofu.

I've gone here and ordered these dishes so often the cashier knows me already.  The lunch portion size is generous and price is good for a downtown SF lunch. 

Beware that dinner prices double though. For the same dishes  the price is double and doesn't come with rice like the lunch order does. 

Note the $10 minimum for credit card charges.
author: Joanne T.

description:
Not anywhere near what I would have expected. Food was very similar to Panda Express, but inferior. The food was rather oily, I felt it had the tell tale signs of MSG written all over it, and the customer service was typically what you would get at a Chinese restaurant - explicitly, you get treated like a number, not a customer. Tried their lunch combo, and the cashier charged an extra dollar because I paid by Debit card, and did not even bother asking me if I was okay with it (a note on the cashier machine says minimum of $10 for debit/credit cards, else there is a surcharge). 

Had read a lot of reviews before going here, expected a pleasant experience, but very much disappointed with quality of food, service and atmosphere. Likely never going to go again :-(
author: Raj D.

description:
What can I say?  I love and hate New Ming's all at the same time!  

The love is for the food - the food is phenominal.  I have never tried the Hofbräu so I have no opinion on this however I always get the same thing as it is hard for me to embrace change.

Today I was craving the house wonton noodle soup.  I get this EVERY TIME I order however today was different because I called-in my order rather than do my normal walk-in and order for takeout.

Today, while at work, on a post-it, I wrote New Ming's telephone number and what I wanted to order: House Wonton Noodle Soup and Salt and Pepper Chicken wings (I originally wrote Korean but changed my mind).  I made the call; I looked at what I wrote on the post-it and ordered.  The nice woman who answered the call repeated my order and I said yes House Wonton Noodle soup.  What I did not realize is; she only registered and repeated Wor Wonton Soup even after I repeated HOUSE wonton noodle soup.  

Needless to say, I picked up my order ($26.75 + $2.25 tip pricey for two items).  I walked back to my office, placed the SOUP in a SOUP BOWL and then noticed the abundance of wontons and LACK of noodles in my NOODLE SOUP.  Huh?  Scratches head.  

I rechecked my post-it and it had the correct name of the soup I wanted.  I then re-called New Ming's and explained that I did not get noodles in my soup and was met with "that's because you order wonton soup, wor wonton soup."  I said, "No. I know what I ordered and it was the HOUSE wonton noodle soup."  

But here is a conundrum and I have to ask:  Wouldn't it be expected that, if someone ordered HOUSE blahty blah blah soup, and there are only TWO HOUSE soups listed on New Ming's menu: House Wonton and House Udon soup, would it be reasonable to expect NOODLES of some kind in my order of the HOUSE soup?

Evidently this assumption was completely missed by the nice woman who took my order.

To reconcile our differences, the nice woman on the phone suggested that I BRING EVERYTHING BACK and she will TAKE OUT some of the wontons and ADD the noodles.  I asked her to repeat this, she did, and I heard her correctly, BRING EVERYTHING BACK and she will TAKE OUT and ADD.  I said thank you and hung up the phone.

UM.  For some people TIME IS MONEY and like these some people, losing my time equals losing my money.  Instead of taking the time to pour the soup back in to the plastic container and walking back over to New Ming's, I decided to chalk this experience up as a lesson.  No more calling my order in but if I do, I need to be VERY CLEAR in what they repeat back to me.  

As for the soup, it was good, but it lacked, well, you know, NOODLES.

As for the Salt & Pepper Chicken wings = Awesome and abundant (I wasn't expecting that many).

And now for your viewing pleasure.
author: Cris B.

description:
3-4 stars, depending on what you order. Congee here is solid, and its definitely a staple when I'm not feeling well. Many of the stir fry dishes have flavors slightly different than what I was expecting, so I have 1-2 favorites I regularly come back for.

Main dining area feels on the newer side and is pretty clean. I usually see the place at least half full, many times with Chinese customers, so I would think the place has a good balance of quality and affordability. Service is quick and friendly, and overall this is a good staple in the area.
author: James S.

description: There aren't many authentic Chinese restaurants south of Fidi in SoMa one is authentic and fast. I recommend their Dan Dan noodle soup.
author: Madhu J.

description:
Easy spot for lunch if you're in the area. The couple times I've been here there's been. long. You can do take out or order in dining. 

There's two separate lines - 1 to pick out the express combo bento and 2 to order the menu. I've only ordered from the menu for the egg shrimp ho fun stir fry (not sure if this is the name on the menu). 

Note that it does take a lot longer for these item to be ready. Call ahead to pick up!! It's very greasy so I would suggest splitting it and order another item with someone else if possible. I don't typically crave Chinese food but don't mind this once in awhile
author: Sherry Y.

description:
I've been here on numerous occasions & still haven't ordered a dish I didn't enjoy.

Highly recommend:
- Hong Kong Style Noodles with Beef (comes with shrimp on the menu, but I ask for beef instead)
- Beef & Tofu with Ho Fun Noodles (I seriously have an insatiable love for tofu & ho fun)
- Chicken Corn Soup (lots of chicken bits--loved!)
- Hot & Sour Soup (standard, but good)
- Pea Sprouts with Garlic (off menu, & about $15-16, but most pea sprout dishes are at this price)
- Spinach with Garlic (cheaper alternative to pea sprouts without the crunch)
- Minced Pork Noodles (noodles are a little bit thicker than the norm, & sauce is flavored well!)

Not open on Martin Luther King, Jr Day!

Overall, my new go-to spot downtown for Chinese food. Can't wait to try more of their dishes!
author: Carol N.

description: This place felt very authentic. There was a wide variety of Asian food to pick from, and I went with the scrambled egg with pork belly (asado) and rice for $9.50. It was a generous serving (a lot of rice!) and came with a great sauce. I would definitely come back here again for a quick lunch!
author: Ashley O.

description: Fast and convenient place to get Chinese food. If you are tired of Panda Express, here is a place to make a change. I personally still like Panda Express even though it's an American-Chinese fast food restaurant chain. At lease Panda makes its food delicious. The food here at New Ming's are also not bad. It's good for a quick bite at lunch break, and easy to order cheap take-outs in this expensive area.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
Okay, I'm updating this review because I frequent this place a lot since I started working just around the corner from it.  This won't be one of those higher-end chinese places where they have a picture of Barak Obama on the wall from his visit.  But, for being in the financial district, it's solid chinese food at a decent price.  They have a pretty extensive dinner menu and everything is solid food-wise.  

I wish they did a decor refresh, so I could comfortably take visitors there.  But as a weekday lunch, they're actually my go-to.
author: Samuel L.

description:
Came back for lunch. Still a solid Chinese place and the service is friendly. 

This time ordered congee (which hit the spot) and wonton soup with beef. The stock and beef were good. The wonton has pork and mushroom which is a different style than I'm used to. Maybe it's meant to be dipped in a spicy sauce, but as is out of the soup, the wonton was a little under seasoned for my taste. 

//

Solid Chinese entry in Soma.  The spicy pork had a dry flavoring that was fragrant and tasty. 

The seafood tofu soup was well flavored. 

Zha jiang mian had a good sauce, but noodle wasn't al dente -- it'd be perfect if there was more chew to the noodle.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
New Ming's is my go-to Chinese restaurant during the work week. It's not what you'd call the "best", but it offers fairly authentic Szechuan food. 

For a quick bite, there's a cafeteria-style lunch line that offers Panda Express-esque food. I never get this because the food is pretty basic.

What I DO get is their sit-down menu, which is way more authentic and delicious. My usuals are the Hot Sauce Fish, Pea Sprouts with Garlic, and Hai Nan Chicken. Free hot tea with your meal, but a little difficult to find seats during lunch hours.
author: Sijia W.

description:
Such the underrated Chinese takeout spot. Was my go to when I was working in the area. The ladies there are nice if you speak Cantonese to them. Some recognize you and hook you up with more food haha!

Recommendations:
The salt and pepper pork chops
The scrambled eggs with beef over rice
The Singapore rice noodles
Can't go wrong with their standard items (don't judge me, tasty is tasty)
author: Gordon L.

description:
Out with the old, and in with the new -- New Ming's right at ya.  2 short blocks from Yelp corporate - talk about performance anxiety!?!  Casual, and well-priced.  Thumbs up.

At lunch, it's a fast food haven.  At the counter, a dozen already made items built for 2 item combos, rice or noodles, and your outta there.  At night, the ladies spend a little time with a daily makeover -- covering up the fast food counter and the signage, and dimming the lights.  Getting the nice dinner menus ready and primed for service.

What you have at New Ming's is a hassle-free, authentic Chinese place.  Look around?  Chinese people eating here!  One mark of, it's gotta be good!  Perhaps it's the other menu items that draw in the ethnic locals, all kinds of soups, noodle dishes, and things with pork intestines and frogs.

For me, I was tame (and timid), I went for dinner.   I tried the Spicy Beef Noodle [$10.95, 4.0 stars] & Salt & Pepper Prawn [$12.95, 4.5 stars] -- both are officially on delicious notice.

If the food is not enough, Paula will delight you with conversation.  Food, yes, but SF city, she's is know-it-all (in a good way!).
author: Randy B.

description:
I've been to New Ming's Restaurant three times and I've enjoyed the food and service each time.  The one thing  that really stands out to me is how clean the restaurant is every time I've been there, you know some restaurants in the city can be a bit sticky.  The service is quick, and friendly, I don't feel rush, I feel they attentive. The menu is big, I'm hoping to work my way through it in time, and everything I've tried has been fantastic.
I often ask Lai, she remember I don't like onions from my first visit, my server for a recommendation and I'm always happy with the selection.  I also feel the food quality and price is fair equitable.  It's as close as you are going to get to a 5 star Chinese restaurant with out paying 5 star prices.
author: David E.

description: Second time ordering from New Ming's in downtown SF, the first time I was introduced to this amazing gem was in the summer of 2017 by a long time loyal customer, and I mean, long time. I wish I could remember exactly what we ordered because it was all amazing and perfectly seasoned. This time around I wanted to try some new items to-go, rice porridge with chicken, shrimp rice place and a good ol' Chinese-American orange chicken! The BART ride smells amazing! Thanks New Ming's for the great job you guys do in providing us with a taste unlike anything else!
author: Karlos G.

description: Mediocre, MSG-filled food. B.S. additional charge for charge card.
author: Athena S.

description: The Szechuan chicken is very bad. Looks authentic but not spicy or sweet at all, completely flavorless. Also the pig intestine hot pot is really flavorless too :( tapioca was good
author: Jessica S.

description:
Seriously, get a decent Chinese meal quickly for under 10 bucks? The cost:value ratio is in our favor. 
Don't get takeout and eat there-you'll get an earful from the staff. Go there for a quick lunch, or takeout to your work.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Let's face it....

When you decide to get lunch at a Chinese buffet like New Ming's you sort of realize that the quality and health quality are not going to be great. You are basically betting that things are fried and drenched in oil. And for the most part you would be right.

Do not get me wrong there are some healthy options here...but the food just tastes bland and mediocre. The fried rice and noodles are just lacking of any soul or taste. 

Everything else I ordered was fried, oily , and well just not good.

In a city with great Asian food options....New Ming's aint one of them!
author: David G.

description:
New Ming's will hit the spot for the fast Chinese food craving. Come in at lunch and get yourself a lunch combo Panda Express style. Their chow mein is really just seasoned thick noodles with soy sauce but it is probably the main reason I love this place.

I always get a 2 combo with the chow mein, probably mixed veggies (really just mostly broccoli, but it's good) and some type of meat. Get the Mongolian beef or something like that.

The line moves super quick, and they have free cold water that spews out really quick, small pet peeve when they provide free water and it dribbles out of the faucet in slow motion. Seats are ample so it's just so damn convenient.
author: Patrick L.

description: A friend and I stopped in for light supper before cinema at SFMOMA. We were pleasantly surprised. We ordered the Shan Tong dumplings (house made, not frozen), and basil braised tofu. If don't like garlic, don't order either of these dishes. My first bite of the Shan Tong dumplings was a burst of garlic and chives... so yummy. They use soft tofu for the basil braised tofu. The sauce was very flavorful. The tofu was nicely braised on the outside and milky smooth on the inside...wonderful. We will be back to try the green onion pancake which is also house made.
author: s k.

description:
After working in the city for over a few months, I'm surprised it took me this long to try New Ming's. 

I ordered the scrambled egg shrimp with chow fun and that was delicious!! They give you a good portion. I ordered it off eat24, so I was also able to use a $2 coupon, which made the deal even more affordable. 

I will definitely be coming back soon when I need my Chinese food fix.
author: Joyce W.

description:
3.5 star rounded up for nostalgia. 

An interesting sight in the increasing gentrified section of Soma, New Ming's is an old school Chinese restaurant that serves up some dishes well known to Chinese people, while keeping it friendly to the neighbourhood American. You can go with their daily specials at the counter (you point, they scoop), but they also have a pretty sizable menu you can order from. 

The lunch specials are large and quite affordable, but if you order items a la carte you could rack up the cost quickly. I ordered some Chong Qing wings as recommended by other places, as well as beef spare ribs with bell peppers over rice, a classic Hong Kong diner dish.

The wings came crispy, spicy, and delicious in all their greasy glory, but I think the recent craze of KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) have moved my bar up. These compare well but aren't significantly better (read: if there's a KFC place nearby you don't need to come here). 

Meanwhile, the beef was a bit too tough, but the sauce was great. It reminded me of the cheapo meals I used to get as a poor student. 

The food wasn't a "must try" in the grand scheme of things. But I still think about it all the time because it reminded me of home so darn much. Perhaps that's worth something.
author: Alice C.

description:
Had the scramble eggs with BBQ pork over rice today ($9.50).  I was expecting scramble eggs with BBQ pork... it was more like an egg omelette with BBQ port over rice.  The served it with a small container of oyster sauce.  The dish itself was a bit bland... so the oyster sauce did help, but it was salty.  

I think if they had sweet sour sauce instead, it might be a bit better.
author: Jerry W.

description:
I was skeptical at first, but New Ming's grew on me. I came here on a number of occasions when I was working nearby. 

it's nice to see some older shops that haven't folded to rampant gentrification. The food isn't the best quality, and neither is the service, but it's consistent and cheap. That goes a long way. 

During the lunch hour, this is a popular spot, and will always have a line. Fortunately, they move pretty quickly, and you're never spending too much time waiting around. 

There's actually a decent amount of seating here, but it's definitely more of a grab-and-go spot. 

The 2 item lunch combo is my go-to.

If you're looking for something super healthy or trendy, this is not the place for you. This is just old fashioned, no frills, Chinese food at cheap prices. I hope it never changes.
author: Daniel M.

description:
I love their shrimp and scrambled eggs over rice!  It's comfort food to the soul.  Add the hot sauce that they have on the counter tables and it's bomb diggity.

Spicy fish in hot oil is yummy.  It enhanced the white rice combo meal.  

Most of the dishes are stir-fried!  Delicious regime.  

They have the standard menu of Canton food hanging and the already made ones on see through display.

Spot on for the munch on lunch.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I came here on my trip to sf and I thought I was going to enjoy it a lot more. It is close to MOMA so we decided to eat here since we wanted Chinese food. My boyfriend got the mangolian beef with fried rice and it was good but I've definitely had better. I got the curry chicken which kinda tasted like soap. Place could be a lot better but the price was cheap.
author: Ashley A.

description: Got tired of convention food and walked over to New Ming's Restaurant. They have two menus, one on the wall and one for sit-down. I ordered the spicy beef stew noodle soup from the sit-down menu. Spicy like fire- spicy but really delicious. The beef stew is thinly sliced like the way it is in Pho but have a wonderful blend of Asian spices. Yum! i will be sure to visit the next time I'm near Moscone.
author: Susan L.

description: Got the duck and Kung pow chicken with chow mein. MeT was mostly bones, the little meat that was there was not good. I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Jasan S.

description: I've been coming to New Ming's since I was a teenager and I'll never forget them. It's really fresh and consistent.
author: Marquise A.

description: Ming's got a remodel which definitely boosts it rating in my book.  Hard to find a basic chinese restaurant that's not super dirty or super pretentious.  Got the classic beef chow fun and it tasted like how I used to have it as a kid back in not hong kong.  Friend got the dan dan which is just aight but if you're ever in soma and are craving some basic but good chinese food stop by MIIIIIIIIIIINGS
author: Vince L.

description: For someone who works in this area, it is nearly impossible to find a good and affordable lunch. New Ming's scores great on both accounts! They have lots of delicious and affordable lunch options! Don't be discouraged if there is a long line during lunch time, the line moves very quickly and they are constantly changing out the pans with hot, fresh food! I usually order the lunch special "Two Items, To-Go, Fried Rice, Orange Chicken and Broccoli Beef" - boom! In and out in under 5 minutes! LOVE THIS PLACE!
author: Matt S.

description: I love New Ming's Chinese restaurant.  One of my favorite neighborhood go to restaurant.  The food is great and love the ladies behind the counter.  They feed me like I am their daughter. :) I usually ordered shrimp fried rice, HK shrimps with eggs over chow-funs.  You must try their Salt/Peppers chicken wings.  The beSt wings ever.  The spicy fish pot is another of our favorites.  None of the dishes here are bad.  I like that they would substitute things in the dishes that you don't like to eat.
author: Michele H.

description: Not impressed with this place. It smells awful inside and the woman working the counter is not friendly. The price is better than most for the area and the food is standard Chinese cuisine. There's a buffet for lunch but I am not sure it's the safest choice. It's about as basic as you can get without the food getting you sick.
author: Jessica D.

description: I tried New Ming's for the first time last week. I live right across the street and hadn't found great Chinese take out yet so I gave it a try. We dined in and had a really basic but good meal. I got beef and vegetables with fried rice and my husband got the duck. Very reasonably priced- will definitely go back.
author: Carol Ann V.

description: My wife and I were at the SFMOMA and I started getting hungry.  I really wanted some Chinese food but did not want to walk or Lyft to Chinatown.  I found New Ming's on Yelp and we were very pleased.  This place is a little hole in the wall but it was pretty busy. The staff was friendly and the food was good, albeit a little salty.  I recommend the twice cooked pork belly, salt & pepper calimari, and kung pao chicken.  I would go there again, next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Mark J.

description:
If you want to get some quick and delicious Chinese food out in upper soma area, New Ming's is your go to spot. It's quick delicious and hits the spot. We always have Chinatown in San Francisco but if New Ming's happens to be closer and you just want to hit that craving, I feel like it would be the better choice. I'm loving the rice cakes and the garlic spinach that they serve, and any of their meat dishes is bomb.

Because it's in a district that is primarily surrounded by commercial businesses, the area is often less crowded in the evenings. So the service is usually very quick in the evenings. In the afternoon, they have the fast express service style so honestly it's always pretty quick.
author: Pat L.

description: Fast, oily, and filling Chinese fare at a reasonable price point. I do wish there were more classic Chinese vegetable staples (e.g. bok choy) to balance out the choices.
author: Josh L.

description: The food is ok . Service is ok. It's very close to my work place. Been here lots of times
author: Clancy Y.

description:
I hadn't been to New Ming's in about 4 years and it was nice to go back and see that nothing has changed - it was still as good as it's always been.

I first remember going to New Ming's about 13 years ago...it's Chinese comfort food at it's best, with all the flavor and reasonable pricing.  Their Sesame Chicken is one of their popular items and it's a perfect balance of savory and sweet.  

The food is heavy and rich so just be prepared for that.  While they are crazy busy during lunch, I typically visit during the day on Saturday when no one is really there and it's great (also one of the few places open int he area on Saturdays).
author: Ken G.

description:
Service is rude. I brought my food but can't eat there. Their excuses was I ordered the food to go... They did not give me an option when I ordered my food. I never experienced this kind of service at any restaurant my whole life in US or other country. The worse part is I offered to pay extra money or I can bring left over with me. Also, I told them that I don't have a place nearby to eat. Their response is stand outside on the street and eat. Ridiculous!!!

I would if I could 0 star!
author: An T.

description: Really good and authentic Szechwan food. You know it is good when you are the only Caucasian in the restaurant. Do not pass up anything with noodles. All proteins are top notch. Service is very friendly and efficient.
author: Cathy G.

description:
Got a quick dinner take out with my boyfriend before watching the warriors game. We originally wanted to go to a Japanese restaurant, but the wait was too long so we decided to come here since it was close by his place. 

I have been craving jai jai mein (black bean noodles) and fried rice and haven't had it since I've been back from Tokyo. The black bean noodles were surprisingly pretty good, they used thicker noodles and a generous amount of black bean sauce with minced beef. It was delicious and sauce was well done, was pretty impressed. Fried rice was very good also, good portions and the rice smelled great with the fried eggs and onions. I was a bit hesitant to eat here, but glad I gave it a try. I wouldn't mine coming here again!
author: Natalie L.

description: Avoid this place if you are looking for authentic Chinese food. This is your typical American-Chinese food. Highly disappointed and will not return.
author: James D.

description: Good food and large portions. Not much of a decor, but who cares when the food is good and affordable. When in San Francisco give it a try.
author: Alfredo K.

description:
Very meh. Went for lunch and did the 3 items + lo mein for $9.65 + tax. The lo mein noodles were pretty saucey but totally bland and lacking good spices. The other three items included a vegetable mix, roasted eggplant and tofu. Eggplant was also soggy and drenched in sauce, vegetable mix could have been cooked longer and the tofu was ok so it ended up being by far the best thing on my plate. 

Definitely would recommend other cheap Chinese restaurants before this one. A reasonable price for my meal would have been $6.95.
author: Alexander C.

description:
As there are somewhat limited food choices in SOMA, either, salad, chinese, lee's, a few sandwich shops, I was gladly surprised by New Ming.

I grew up with chinese, so I am super picky when someone says that they know a good chinese place. This place has your classic lunch line, which for $9 for three sides, is super generous, portion was huge that I shared with my co-worker.

I got the veggie mix, cumin pork and fried chicken. I wish I saw the dry fired green beans and that they were not out of the fried pork. But overall it was tasty. 

Is there MSG in it...maybe?

But it was good, the chicken was not dry and crispy. The cumin pork was seasoned well and the veggies were fine. I prefer chow fun over chow mein, so I got rice with my food.

If you want to order off the menu, you have to go to the line on the left, and I want to try their wontons.

They take card, but only after $10, so bring cash if possible.
author: Mei L.

description: Great place for lunch. One of the dwindling places to get Chinese-American food downtown.
author: Dino N.

description:
I've been both for dinner and lunch.

The lunch pickup is a little chaotic, and there are a lot of options to choose from. I hear the cafeteria style choices are better value, but I wanted snow pea greens, so I ordered a la cart.

At dinner, I had beef tendon, pea greens, and something else (it was a while ago) and I remember being quite pleased. Looking forward to coming again!
author: B C.

description: Efficient and friendly service with very affordable prices. The Cantonese dishes are very authentic and hit the spot. Some of my favorites are: mapo tofu rice, Chiuchow tofu rice, Thai-style vermicelli and fried fish with creamed corn over rice. I've tried a few of their Sichuan dishes but they were meh. I think it's best to stick with Cantonese dishes at this place.
author: Nerdy P.

description:
The thing with Chinese food is it's either really good or really bad.. New mings reaallllly good.. 
Wor won ton soup request it with bok choy and a side of white vinegar and hot oil always served piping hot PERFECTION
Salt & pepper calamari is comparable to Thanh Long TO DIE FOR! 
The lunch buffet garlic chicken salt & pepper pork chop AMAZING 
Never hit and miss always on point.. I know this because I've been dining and taking out here since 2010.. Hella clean with the same lil ladies behind the counter and bussing the tables since the 1st day I walked in this joint. I often bring my family here after work hours for dinner. Try today you will thank me tomorrow.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Ming's is in a prime location, fast, cheap, and tasty. 

First off, it's right next to my office away from home so of course, I have to visit. 
The prices are pretty insane. The food is cheap even if it were in the podunk town. Two different "meats" and fried rice for 8.25? I'll take it. Plus it's pretty tasty...especially considering you can get in and out faster than McDonald's. 

I got the fried rice, sesame chicken, and broccoli+beef. Yes, I went with fairly safe choices but can you blame me? I could have opted for something a little more authentic but I didn't know where to starts so I stuck to my guns.
author: Aaron B.

description: This place is a great!! It's definitely one of a few best Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. I like their BBQ fried rice, general tsao chicken and any braised tofu dishes. Everything is really flavorful and not oily!
author: Clare L.

description:
This place is pretty good for some quick chinese food if you work in the area. Can get a 2-combo to go for pretty cheap, and the line moves quickly. Try the cumin pork, it tastes great!

Back when I worked in this area, I'd come here about once a week. There are more specialized dishes that you can get if you can read the chinese characters on the wall, too.

I've also gotten the salt and pepper tofu here, it was fairly good, but (as with most fried things) make sure that it can vent, otherwise the entire dish will turn soggy quickly!
author: Alexander L.

description: Maybe the made to order dishes are better but the buffet is on par with suburban mall.   Cheap prices for downtown SF is it's best feature.
author: Mike G.

description: Going to give it 2 stars.  It is a little bit average to below average Chinese food.  The scoop out of the counter food looked ok and for the price is probably great. We ordered off the regular menu and it is just overpriced for what it is.  The dumplings were $9 and I could of gotten them in NY for $2 (same amount). Foregoing price, they weren't that tasty.  The beef and tofu also had no flavor.  The salt and spicy wings were okay but also not worth $14.  I was like, "didn't I just order 2 dishes and 1 appetizer?  Why does it cost $42."  oh yeah, they charge for white rice too.  I consider that a sin at Chinese restaurant when you pay $14 for a entree.  makes me want to switch it to 1 star, but I'll let it go.
author: David N.

description: Really awesome service and delicious food. Great place to chow down Chinese food in SoMa.
author: Jordan K.

description: Not the best Chinese food, but also not bad for $8 bucks. I came here for the lunch special along with a co worker of mine. We arrived around 11:45am and were lucky to beat the afternoon lunch rush. I ordered the fried rice, egg roll and sesame chicken. On top of that I got a coca cola so it came out to about $10 bucks for me which is an absolute steal in this area of the city. The rice was quite good and the chicken was tasty too sweet and tangy a bit. The egg roll was a bit too greasy though and didn't have much flavor. The staff was working hard and I wouldn't say they were the nicest, but hey I wasn't there to talk much. The place is kind of small, so finding a table can be difficult if you're trying to eat there, so take out may be your best option. Overall decent and would probably go back for a quick fix for Chinese.
author: James R.

description:
Just stumbled into this place. Very good Kung pat chicken and won ton soup!  Local place for sure!

I'll be back!
author: Tony T.

description: Tasty chinese food! We ate there with three persons, three different dishes, and all three tasted great. We all agreed this was good food! Would love to go back and try other dishes!!
author: Roberta P.

description: This place is average.  In a city like San Francisco I would only go here if the location is convenient.  They may have good lunch deals but for dinner New Ming's is definitely $$ not $ with average size dinner portions.   We had the Kung Pow which I give a 3 of 5 and the Orange Beef which I give a 2 of 5.  Might go back, but will need to research which dishes are house favorites.
author: K Y.

description: Okay place for times that you can't cook. Fast, reliable service. I just have to tell them not too much oil each time I order. Otherwise, it's fine!
author: Lisa D.

description:
Chung Qing Wings - 2/5 - 7x7. Average salt and pepper wings but for some reason they cut it in half before frying. This led to a lot of loose bones which is not fun. 
Egg rolls - 2/5

Overall, "I've experienced better." There are better Chinese take out places around.
author: Mark O.

description:
Basically, Chinese food is the new fast food. And New Ming's has this idea down! I was in and out of there in about 5 minutes during lunch time.

They do have a full menu but for lunch, you really just want their $6-9 lunch specials, which comes with your choice of chow mein, fried rice, or steamed rice. And they probably expect you to order the lunch special too because as soon as you get to the counter, they point to the lunch special and ask if you want chow mein, fried rice, or steamed rice. Everything's really quick and you have to be on your toes so you don't hold up their line.

You get to choose up to 3 of their lunch items that they have out, so it's kinda like Panda Express. But better because I think it's more legit than Panda Express (the staff speaks full-on Cantonese or Mandarin). I got the Sesame Chicken and Mixed Veggies with my chow mein. There's a hint of honey mustard in the Sesame Chicken, which is interesting. So it doesn't super taste like sesame at all actually. But it's still yummy. The broccoli was crunchy, just the way I like it. The chow mein was kinda bland.

They do accept card but minimum $10. Might have to make this a regular lunch place and maybe, I'll branch out from their lunch specials eventually. But that one-dollar sign for lunch in the Financial District though...
author: Athena C.

description:
TL;DR: Although New Ming's looks like an average and nondescript Chinese restaurant, it's actually one of the best in the city. Skip the cafeteria style stuff if you want their best. My Chinese (from Xian and Wuhan) co-workers tried all of the Chinese restaurants within walking distance of our office, and this was one of two they chose.

I've been there a lot, it's a big menu so here's a few tips:

Fried Calamari: A coworker order this, I was skeptical but this is a great salt/pepper/garlic/halapenjo thing. Not spicy.

Chung King Wings: still my favorite version of this dish in the city. Salt, Red Chiles, Sichuan peppercorns

Salt and Pepper Green Beans: a traditional Chinese favorite, here with Sichuan peppercorns

Hot and Numbing Spicy Fish Pot: there's two soups you want to order here, it's a bit easier to order from the big menu with the pictures so that you can tell the "red" from the "clear". This is the clear, served on a burner to keep it hot. Forget about ordering this one out. You have to eat this one in. Chief counsel at our company described the floral flavor of this dish as "almost pretty". Perhaps too much of a kick to be pretty?

Clay pot beef and bamboo shoot: More tendon than beef but who cares? Salty and sweet and rich, punctuated with bamboo shoots. I'm always torn between this one and the beef tendon and tofu. This one *is* better, but not by much.
author: Seth G.

description: Love the scrambled egg hor fun!
author: Yijun L.

description:
OLD MING'S (PUSHUP CHICKEN) & NEW MING'S  (FRIED FLOUNDER FISH OVER RICE)

At the Old Ming's near my work (my office had moved since) I would order the pushup chicken that came with steam rice, gravy, and butter corn. What's a pushup chicken? It looks like chicken lollipop. Let me explain. Separate the chicken wings by cutting between the drumette and wingette. For the drumette with the knife scrape the meat on the bottom to push the meat to the other side of the bone. For the wingette first cut off the wing tip. Then take off the smaller bone. With the remaining bone push the meat from one side of the bone to the other side. That's how dish is named as pushup chicken. With the gravy, sweet corn, and rice I referred this dish as the Chinese version of a country style fried chicken. The chickenjoy at Jollibee is similar to this dish except the pushup chicken uses only chicken wings. Due to the uniqueness and taste of the pushup chicken my boss and I would order this dish at the Old Ming's if we were craving for fried chicken. For a couple of years it seemed every other Friday I would go to the Old Ming's for pushup chicken. The Old Ming's has been closed for several years as most of the employees have moved to the New Ming's.

At the New Ming's I was sadly informed that the pushup chicken isn't on the menu anymore as the cook who used to cook this specific dish had retired. However one dish I used to order at the Old Ming's is at the New Ming's - fried flounder fish over steamed rice. What makes the fried founder fish special is the breading. It is heavily breaded that makes this dish very crispy. You would think heavy breading would make the dish heavy when it's fried but it's the total opposite. The heavily breaded flounder keeps the meat moist inside. The head, tail, and fun is so crispy you can eat them as fish chips due to the heavy breading. Since the flounder is heavily breaded the breading isn't soggy. The flounder isn't a thick fish but with this dish you can eat the bones inside the fish. The heavy breading is similar to fish and chips but instead of a filet fish you get a whole fish that's deep fried. 

When I come to the New Ming's the only dish I order is the fried flounder fish. I hope one of these days the pushup chicken is back on the menu.
author: Gerald R.

description:
TL;DR: skip the steam plate line, order Dan Dan 

Like Jeannie below, I got the spicy numbing beef stew today. It was good, but...

You HAVE to get the Dan Dan noodle soup!

Every time I'm in the area, I stop in to get it. Even if I just ate. It comes with perfect little pieces of salty ground pork in a similar chili oil broth with the same great thick noodles as the numbing beef. Some great leafy greens really round out the noodle soup. 

Crowded at lunch time. Don't be afraid to share your table with a stranger! We all gotta eat! We all gotta eat Dan Dan!
author: Adam Z.

description:
Reviewing this place as TAKE-OUT CHINESE FOOD PLACE and it delivered!

... well actually, I picked it up but you know. Here's how I felt about my experience:

Timeliness +++!
The boyfriend said, oh this place is never on time. Well, guess we (they?) showed him! Ordered on Eat24, said we would pick it up at 815pm, arrived at 814pm.... BAM, they had it ready!

Food ++
War wonton soup- for I am sick and in need of soup. Plenty of veggies, meat and wontons. However, my already parched lips shriveled further from the saltiness of the broth. 

Price +++!
2 full size to-go containers of war wonton soup... and the price was just $20! Worth. 

Overall, I wouldn't make a trip out here just for the food, but if I'm in the area and am looking for a cheap Chinese take-out place... New Ming's my place! :)
author: Jessica L.

description: I've found my new favorite Chinese food in the financial district. Everything i've had so far is fantastic...and their service is so attentive. I love their special chicken dishes, including the bucket chicken and spicy chef chicken. We also had braised duck with tofu. Walnut shrimps is one of the best we've tasted in San Francisco. Overall a great restaurant for a hearty meal~~
author: Fay F.

description:
Best place for authentic Chinese food on weekdays!
Good price as well! Recommend to order from the menu.
author: Jane H.

description:
I would like to start this review by stating that if you think fried rice and chow mien and orange chicken are Chinese food you're really welcome to leave right now. The city. Sorry I know some really nice people who like that stuff. It's fine, no, it really is. But keep that shit to your Trader Joe's frozen food section shopping list! I'm almost sorry.

That said, New Ming's is a sheep in wolf's clothing, which I think is a weird analogy that it seems terrible but is actually great. Nothing against wolves though. Go with me here.

Anyway skip the cheap lunch and go for some of the Szechuan dishes and other delights.
The CHICKEN WINGS. So crispy. Seriously so crispy. So crunchy. 
Tea smoked duck is flavorful and fun and those little duck bones look really cute next to the chicken bones...
Salt and pepper green beans were a good vegetable.

The only thing to say is that it's perfect for where it is and for the expectations you would normally accrue around this place. It's not the best ever but it does it rather right. 

Maybe you'll end up singing a new song -- The New Ming's New Sing

The end.
author: Maya L.

description: Having grown up in a Sicilian household that ate tripe at least once a month, I lunged at the opportunity to try the pig intestine. The clay pot was sizzling with intestine when it came out and I knew immediately it was legit--and oh baby, it was legit! The sauce was a dream and the intestine was like melted butter rolling off the tofu. I hope I don't make it to REM sleep tonight so that I can wake up having dreamed about that sizzling intestine from SF...
author: Pittston P.

description: been here a lot before.  today was my first return after a long time.  got a 3 item combo to go for 10.60...fried rice, tofu string bean, cumin pork, general fried chicken.  quick to go, i was in and out in a few minutes.  tasty and reliable.  the place was packed with people dining in.
author: Richard M.

description: I forgot about this wonderful, delicious Chinese "Hole in the wall" lunch spot! From Cha Siu Won Ton Mein, Mi Fun, Spicy Chow Fun to everything else on their menu, their food is DELISH and this restaurant is better than many Chinatown restaurants! Restaurant is always clean and the service efficient. Will return again soon! I always leave Happy and Satisfied with their yummy dishes!  :0)
author: Aaa T.

description:
Not a fan. 
This place seems like an authentic version of Panda Express because it's run by Chinese folks, but really it's not. It has the same self serve idea as other fast food Chinese places and the same kind of dishes, but the food is definitely below par. 

I got fried rice, sesame chicken, and another kind of chicken which was dark. 
None of these was the slightest bit tasty. How can you go wrong with Chinese fried rice??
The sesame chicken was deep fried but it wasn't soaked well enough in the gravy so it felt more like eating bad chicken nuggets. The other chicken was alright I suppose, but the fried rice just didn't go well. 

As for the restaurant itself it's pretty noisy and folks are always in line. 
There's also love seafood in the aquarium that you walk past when you get in line. And a big aquarium at that! So I suppose if you order the catfish or the lobster from the alacart menu it might be more savory. 

The place was cheap, Cody me only $8 for 2 entree plus rice but there are plenty of places I can think of that are similar prices but more tasty. (DragonEats, Chipotle, SuperDuper)

The staff could use some training on smiling and serving too.
author: Arjan N.

description: This place is cheap and it does not have a long line during busy San Francisco lunchtime.
author: Cam Z.

description:
Lines out the door during their lunch specials.  The mass produced lunch special is on par with most cafeteria bulk food.  Mediocre and low grade for cheap price.
Very passable, sit down and don't order from the troff

However that being said, the dinner 
Food here is authentic Chinese, though they have traditional American faire too like orange chicken.

Their winter melon pork soup is old world with fat and skin and all.  Nice bite to the pork. Pot sticker is moist and supple too and crispy on bottom.  Very good ying and yang

Portions here are small, 1/2 size of what one would find in sunset or millbrae
author: David H.

description:
This place accepts credit cards OVER $10.. and most dishes are ~$7.

Their jook is super watery, but good for the first couple of bites.
The wonton noodle soup with duck is alright. The duck gets mushy real quick.
Coconut milk tea was actually the best thing I had from here.

For a quick Chineseish lunch, it's alright. I'll come back because it's convenient and somewhat satisfying.
author: Angela L.

description: Really good place for authentic Chinese food. Cheap and great food. Seafood and Beef is amazing. Financial District people is a must try.
author: Asad K.

description:
They have pre-made food in heated trays if you want to order those lunch # of items specials. You can also get made to order noodles and rice plates. Usually this is the better route since it is fresher and tastes better. Four stars for low price and convenience.

Opens from 10 am - 9 pm so no need to trek to Chinatown for decent Chinese food. Good for late afternoon lunches as many nearby venues closes once the lunch crowd dissipates. That's the most positive thing I can think of as the food here is okay (thinking of old world countryside food stands).

Milestone: the 5,000th "Funny" vote's review!
author: Peter L.

description: I love th their food. I enjoy everything on their menu. Great amount of portions, but a little too expensive, so I can only splurge every once in a awhile.
author: Anthony B.

description: I eat this place a lot, because I live across the road at The Paramount.... this place is good. Legit, no fortune cookie, served family style, if you come around 8:00ish, they are literally eating there like a family.
author: Joey R.

description: Soid meal. Decent crowd for a Wednesday night. I'd come back next time I'm in SF. Try the hot jasmine tea.
author: Bill K.

description: The customer service is jokingly awful but the food is ok. Prices suck too, to be honest.
author: Jovan W.

description: This food provoked my friend and I to have a plethora of questions--we were not sure if we actually ate food. It was a new experience. The food was definitely horrendous, but of a scale we could not describe. Our stomachs are still uncomfortable. The worst and most questionable "food" I have ever ingested.
author: Fadel F.

description: Staff is friendly, good selection of food, and it's fast.  The food is average at best though.
author: Mark B.

description: Need to improve the health score. I used to visit this place often but with the current score is hard to trust.
author: Carlos G.

description: Hidden gem. Fish and bean curd in clay pot is personal favorite. Solid overall. Have been here 2x now and will continue coming back.
author: Shane W.

description:
Greasy Chinese takeout at its best! 
The chongqing fried chicken lives up to its hype. 
The chow mein is as authentic as a fortune cookie, but strangely satisfying and comforting. Even though I've never, ever eaten anything like that in Asia. 
The boba is on point, especially if you get it with less milk.
Cheap, fast, and yummy. 
Too bad (or thankfully) my office is nowhere close to this place anymore.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I went to this place for lunch on 4/5/17 based on a recommendation from a friend and I got FOOD POISONING!!!! I will NEVER eat here again!!!! I should've known something was wrong when everything I ordered tasted bland and flavorless. I wish I had checked the reviews beforehand because then I would've seen the warning that pops up stating they have a poor food safety score in the lower 5% compared to other restaurants in the area!! There are so many restaurants in the financial district to choose from so, don't waste your money or health on this dump!
author: Shawn B.

description:
This was my go to lunch place!

If I didn't get this each time I'd crave for it :)
* cumin pork
* fried chicken
* salt pepper pork chop (but comes with lots of fat)

All the above I found very good and was almost a regular!

* beef and broccoli (I think they count how many pieces they give you)
* chow mien noodles

Well actually I tried everything in the buffet line and still give high ratings. I tried stuff on the menu and well.. It's not great but it's not bad. So I stick to the lunch specials :)
author: Shine S.

description:
This place is awesome! This is the best Chinese restaurant on this side of Market St. 

The steamed dumplings are really good. Very good. Simple and to the point, just like how a Chinese grandma would make it. 

I haven't tried every dish on the menu yet, but every dish I've eaten so far has been excellent.
author: Richard S.

description: The food is better than your generic American Chinese food. The eggplants were tender and well seasoned. The cumin pork did not have any cumin flavour, nevertheless it was good.
author: James S.

description: Tip: Cumin pork is AMAZING! It's also cash only I think for items less than $10.
author: Gitanjali R.

description: Decent food. Good portion size for the money. Friendly service.  Large menu selection (aka various regions of Chinese food covered.  This is my go-to spot whenever I get a craving for Chinese and I don't want to spend a lot of money or waste a lot of time.
author: Oliver S.

description: Worst Chinese food I ever have in SF. They don't even have high chair for a child. I would not recommend this place.
author: Raul J.

description:
Typical Chinese spot for eating in or take out. They have steam plates for 1-3 item options. Good portions for a decent price (in the Financial district). They also have menu items. If you're not ordering from the steam plates, proceed directly to the cashier to place your order or call in. 

I normally get the numbing beef stew noodle soup. It's pretty greasy but it's good. Can't have it every day, but it's one of those dishes that will hit the spot on a cold day in SF. If you can't handle heat or aren't used to the Szechuan peppers, don't order it. 

Their salt and pepper pork isn't bad either, but beware that a lot of the pieces were just mainly fat. Major disappointment when you are expecting meat. Not horrible but not the best. Haven't tried too many other items, but it looks good and the place is packed with people during lunch.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I don't think I'll come here shortly...:/ When you walk in, you would see pink posters all over the restaurant. It said "if you get it to-go, you can't eat here!" 

Let me explain why I usually get it for to-go. 1)I had my lunch in the restaurant once, but I couldn't finish it. I asked it for the to-go box and they said they had to charged the box and bag. For the bag charge I understand. All the restaurants do that but the to-go box... 2) the proportion is big for a girl so usually I need to get it to-go and save it for later. 

Food is so so based on I'm Taiwanese, and I have tried so many Chinese food. However, it's worthier than the LEE's cross the street(they charge by pounds of food you get). 

I haven't eat here over a year,  today I came back and I disappointed. 

-Food wasn't that good as last time I tried. The tofu is bland, and they spooned you the food mostly are sauce from the dish. Not the food. 
-They charged you a bag without asking you.
-Customer service wasn't that friendly especially the cashier lady. 
-I'm pretty sure they round up the total price. ( I got three items and they came with automatically charged bag; after tax it is supposed around $9.3 or less, but I pay $9.5)
author: Chi Yi L.

description:
I grabbed their mapo tofu to go for dinner along with some additional rice. I'm a big fan of mapo tofu but theirs disappointed me a bit. I found this odd sweet, tangy type taste in it that i later attributed to the texture of the pork mince they were using. It wasn't bad but tasted definitely strange to me. 

Additionally they give a lot of the mapo tofu but very little rice in comparison. I'm not sure why that was the case but it ended up with mapo tofu left over. Perhaps the dish is meant for family style sharing. Plus points for their speed. I ordered and had my dish so quickly, they had to tap me to tell me it was ready
author: Nicholas N.

description:
New Mings was a restaurant that my friend recommended to me. I wanted to try something quick and delicious when I'm in the city. My friend was on point with the recommendation. I went into the restaurant and was quickly seated. The workers are very friendly and took my order when I needed them to. I ordered the minced pork over noodles and it was really good. It also got me full.  

I recommend this restaurant to people who wants something quick when they're on break for work or when they don't want to wait at another restaurant.
author: Dickson W.

description:
Not a fan , I visited this place last Sunday food was not so
Good  , we were so Hungry ordered different fried rice from them that was gross It's not even hot we barely ate few spoons and rice seems so dried disappointed and this place is of all women but we should not expect some smiling and good service from them they overcharged me on my credit card it was 31 dollars but they charged me 45$ . Next time when you visit make sure you charged correctly and never going back . Horrible service
author: Bunny R.

description: Dishes were pricey and tasted bland. Portions were a little smaller than I would've liked, considering the taste and price. Quick service with attentive servers. Quiet atmosphere; I think most people get togo as opposed to dining inside the establishment.
author: Angelica N.

description:
Fairly unremarkable Chinese food located conveniently close to the Westin. We tried the XO chow fun, braised tofu with green beans, and salt and pepper squid - the latter was definitely the star.

While the staff was very accommodating of our toddler, they didn't have any high chairs - surprising.
author: Sharon Y.

description: I don't usually eat Chinese food but they were quick and really nice. I had the Mongolian beef and it was actually really good!
author: Chris P.

description:
This is a great place for a quick bite or take out They have a pretty extensive menu of Szechuan and Canto food (an odd pairing since one is extremely spicy and the other absolutely not).

I ordered the fish and tofu claypot for take out. Service was quick - it only took 5-10 min, and the servers were friendly. The tofu was great, but the fish was slightly on the salty side. Both were cooked to just the right tenderness. The prices are decent for the area, but unfortunately, rice is sold separately. 

I'll definitely come back again to pick up take out on a night in, but I probably won't be coming here to eat with friends and family for a nice sit down meal.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
Call me crazy for giving this place five stars. I simply had that special feeling. It's definitely not one of your downtown-type restaurants. Think of the cafeteria style fast food Chinese restaurants at the mall. This happens to be one in the hustle of Downtown SF and is a restaurant in itself. New Ming's is simple in design, decor, service and food. 

For a restaurant in a city that has a higher cost of living than most, the prices are very reasonable. Rice and two items are a measly $5.95. I had the pork cumin and the eggplant combination. Both dishes were excellent and I sat there eating my lunch doing my happy dance. I was stoked that they had hot oil at all the tables.  

In comparison to the fancier spots that you'll find Downtown this place doesn't stand a chance. But stack these folks up on a simple scale and they win, hands down. You'll get a quick and very delicious and tasty meal within a matter of minutes. This will certainly be one of my quick and cheap eats spots when I'm back in the Bay Area.
author: Xerxes N.

description: Today I ordered their newest addition to their specialty drinks - the Iced Milk. This is the most unique tasting iced beverage I've had in a really long time. It has a frothy consistency, comparable to a light frappe but unlike drinking frapuccinos, it is a drink you won't get tired of sipping on. Their food is consistently tasty and this drink is a happy surprise.
author: Fiona Y.

description: Ignore all the negative reviews, this place is the bomb. I live nearby and we eat here 3-4 times a week. My personal favorites so far are the orange chicken, wor wonton soup, and pan-fried noodles. I personally like the subtley rude service, however thorough and attentive, so don't be put off by this, they are warm and friendly. Tip for the negative reviewers- there is a P.F. Chang's and a Panda Express in Emeryville.
author: Lisa S.

description:
The general decor of this place is very canteen-like, in that you first order and pay for your food at the cash register before the food is brought to you.

However, once the food arrives, you can instantly tell that this is actual authentic Chinese food, and NOT the cheap American-ized low-grade dishes that I had initial suspected. I ordered the "Fuqi feipian", which is a traditional Sichuan dish that is complex to make and are usually only available in authentic Chinese restaurants. To my pleasant surprise, the version they served was pretty close to what I would usually get at formal Chinese restaurants. I would definitely recommend coming to this place more often whenever you're in the area.
author: Henry L.

description:
good spot to hit up if your in the area for the week or just a day, get here early and there is no lines, 11:50am hahaha

ordered their cumin pork and salt & pepper pork chops over some fried rice, the cumin pork was overly greasy for me the salt n pepper pork chop was good but slightly cold, fried rice was standard, if your looking for a filler and want something better then panda express this is definitely the place you want, inexpensive and quick

food ***
service *** quick and efficient
price$
ambiance *** clean, open, not to loud
author: Clarence A.

description:
This place is mostly about chicken-, prawn-, beef- or pork-flavored grease, which is pretty sad. 

If don't have time to wait in line to get seated or you need to get full pretty quickly this might be a place for you. 

Other than that - a substandard Chinese-American restaurant. 
And prices are not that low for the quality.

Service was fine.
author: Piotr G.

description:
Super duper fast lunch with lots of grease! As a Cantonese person, the flavor profile of New Ming's is right up my alley in that it's oily, salty, and slightly sweet -- all flavors I actually grew up on. You can think of the cafeteria-style lunch line as a more authentic Panda Express. 

The prices must have gone up because a 2-entree lunch is $6.58 and a 1-entree lunch is $5.48. But it's a great bang-for-your-buck if you're looking for calories!

New Ming's is also great for getting porridge to go. Whenever I'm sick, I put in my order of fish porridge, bring it back to the office, and hope I don't burn myself because that stuff's made to order. 

I've also had dinner here before, ordering the Cumin Pork and Fried String Beans. Both were actually very salty, which I've noticed a lot of with their lunch dishes as well, but you really can't beat the price.
author: Virginia T.

description: authentic Chinese food in the financial district, you can either order 1 to 3 items from the counter or sit down and order like in a regular Chinese restaurant. we had the sit down version and ordered a veggie dish (with bamboo shoot and winter melon, the dish is very good, light taste and nutritious). we ordered ordered pork intestine, it is not as good as the authentic Chinese restaurants you find in the suburbs, but for downtown restaurant, i think New Ming is one of the best
author: Emily H.

description: This place gives a lot of food at a great price. I normally get the two item with chow mein.  I really like the orange chicken and chicken mushroom.  It's usually busy at lunch time but the line goes fast. They also have noodle soups but I haven't tried those yet.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Food is decently priced (2 item combo $6.xx). The food was pretty good, a lot better than Panda Express or any other kind of chinese food chain IMO. Service was quick and easy to deal with. 

Only problem is in order to use your Debit/Credit, your order must be at least $10. So if a 2 item combo is $6.xx, then surely you will need cash.
author: Robbie P.

description: A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. I ordered fried noodles and two dishes- broccoli and chicken with special sauce which is a little sweet. A little greasy, but delicious.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I finally tried this upon my siblings' request and it's a solid 4 stars. Nice, clean, modern decor. Wat tan hor fun and porridge are good, as well as the tofu and eggplant dishes. Fantastic comfort food, especially if you're down with a cold.

Wonton soup is average and apparently the Zha jiang mian is too salty so will avoid that.
author: Letitia L.

description:
You don't have to go to Chinatown for great Chinese food.  This is my new go to place when I'm out drinking on 2nd street or at nearby Novela. 

I usually get the beef chow fun, or the crispy pan fried shrimp chow mein.  Another  great item is the calamari and goes down good with a beer.

The decor here is typical of most Chinese restaurants, which is outdated cheap decor and not much to look at.  But hey, your here for the food and the friendly service!
author: James H.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurant that I been to while visiting San Francisco. Their food is very fresh and delicious. The fried chicken wings was the BEST!!! Their service was friendly and quick. Very clean and spacious place to eat at. 

I will definitely have to come back to eat here when I come back to SF one day. :)
author: Shirley Y.

description: Great food but very rude and nasty service. My issue is with to go food. I order food to go from the menu and wait for my order. It comes and I proceed to eat a few bites before leaving. Rude lady tells me to leave the restaurant because in eating in myself to go box. I politely explain I wanted a few bites before leaving. The lady told me to leave. Take in mind the restaurant was practically empty. Plenty of seats for dine in customers. Great food but Rude mean women running things here. Oh and yes I read the sign take your To go box with you.
author: Andre D.

description:
Don't let the boring exterior of this place fool you!! The Sichuan food here tastes very homemade! The usual thirstiness from msg will not be found here, which is a plus. 

I came with a couple of my friends and we ordered a beef soup, black bean sauce noodles(MUST TRY!!), 2 types of vegetables, milk tea(MUST TRY!!), and the korean fried chicken.

The beef soup and vegetables reminded me of my parents', and the korean fried chicken was okay, not a show stopper.

The black bean sauce is AMAZING! Milk tea is perfect. It isn't too sweet and it's better than a lot of other milk tea places. 

This place is a must try:)
author: Shannon Y.

description: Ordered a noodles there and it was disgusting, I don't know how they managed to do that. Stay away from this place.
author: Idan L.

description: First time going and food is pretty good! For $8.75 I got fried rice, fried garlic chicken, and beef and broccoli. To go plate was plentiful. Food was great. Good flavor and not super oily or greasy! Will be back to try other dishes.
author: E C.

description:
New Ming's is my go to lunch spot. I could really eat here every day but I try to limit myself. A lot of people walk in and just see the lunch buffet where you can pick and choose what you want. To me this isn't Chinese food, but to each their own. But to be clear, I have actually never tried the buffet so I can comment on the quality.

Growing up going to Oakland Chinatown for dinner every week with my family to have authentic Chinese food I can definitely say I've been spoiled with some great Chinese food. It's really hard for me to find other Chinese restaurants that have that comfort food feeling every time I go back to Oakland but New Ming's definitely gives me this feeling. They have all of my favorite dishes growing up that I can rarely find elsewhere. I have yet to leave New Ming's unhappy.

The trick is to make sure that you order from the menu, not the buffet. There are a plethora of delicious dishes that most people over look or don't even know exist that you can order there and those are the best! They are made to order and come out of the kitchen piping hot! Also a requirement for me. I like my Chinese food super fresh.

My go to dish is rice cakes with minced pork. That is my childhood in a dish and it is delicious ever single time. My sister will actually take an uber to trek across town to have lunch with me here just for the rice cakes. We'll often share a plate of red chili oil wontons as well too. The wontons are absolutely perfect and the bowl of red chili oil is very deceiving. Since there is so much chili oil you assume that you are going to burn your mouth off but is actually very mild and the perfect kick. I'll even take some of that chili oil to put on my rice cakes!

Their wonton noodle soup is perfect for a rainy day or if you just need a bowl of soup. I love their black pepper beef when I am craving a rice dish with a kick of spice. Their dan dan noodles are great as well. Just make sure not to wear white that day because the chili oil splashes every where! I made that mistake once and learned my lesson within the first couple of bites. There is still so much I need to try there and I can't wait. Every time I walk in I see something else I want to try but it's hard to not get the rice cakes.

If you walk in and all the seats are taken don't turn around. There is a secret dining room downstairs that you can go down in eat in too!  This review should really be a 4.5 stars. I absolutely love this place but can't exactly give it 5 stars but it is so close! Overall, if you are looking for a quick lunch spot where you want to get some great Chinese food, I highly recommend New Ming's. And when you come in, don't be surprised when you find me downstairs noming on some rice cakes.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
This review is purely on New Ming's poor business ethics, not on their food.  I have been ordering their food for takeout since I moved to the area mid August.  I like their food.  I started from ordering 6+ dishes each time a couple of times a week to now only 1-2 dishes per order once a week or 2 weeks due my suspicion of their intentional hidden overcharges.  After I confirmed today that they have been overcharging me by rounding up to the dollars without letting me know about it and they admitted that's their normal practice to round up the cents.  Ever since I noticed that I have been overcharged after my 4th large orders, I brought it to their attention and asked them why the total amounts are more and the tax percentage they are charging.  They told me they charge 8.75% which is normal.  At the time they told me that they charge 10 cents for each bag which is fine but I was still charged more than the # of bags.  I let it go at that time.  Most merchants ask in advance if we want bags before charging us for them.  They however advised me that I need to notify them in advance that I do not need bags.  Ever since I notify them in advance that I have my own bags and have been ordering one or just two items to test if the total amounts would be more accurate without the hidden overcharges.  That worked for a few orders with accurate total amount or just with a few cents round up by them which I don't think it's ethical.  Most ethical businesses would check with the customer if it's ok to round up the two cents.  If they don't want to check with the customer and don't want to deal with the pennies, they would round it down.  I have always paid with credit card which wouldn't cause them penny issues.  Not sure why they think it's ok to automatically charge their customers more.  But if just a few pennies, even though I don't appreciate them rounding up without my permission, I wouldn't bother bringing it up again to them and cause confrontation.  But they overcharged me again after I placed a larger order (only 3 items) today.  After I noticed that I have been overcharged, I have been calculating the exact total amount I should be charged for my orders before I go to the restaurant.  Today my order total should be $37.90 and the total they gave me was $38.  I asked her how did you come up with $38.  The accurate total amount should be $37.90.  She told me that "no problem, we just round up the small numbers.  If the dish is $12.98, we round up to $13.  No problem.".  I said to her, no problem for you but there's a big problem for me.  First of all, I do not like to be overcharged for the hidden price increase.  Second, it's unethical and deceptive for them to round up without their customers' knowledge.  The items from my order today were $12.95, $12.95, and $8.95.  I don't know how she rounded up to adding 10 cents more.  I also do not understand how they believe it's ok for them to round up from $12.95 to $13 at the time of payment without letting their customer know about it.  It's upsetting that they have been telling me one lie after another and they don't add up.  I gave them the benefit of the doubt and tried to believe they made mistakes, but now knowing that they knowingly overcharge their customers without their customers' knowledge and believe there is no problem about it, that bothers me.  What else they have been stealing from their customers secretly?  It's unfortunate that I have to give up dining at this restaurant and no more takeouts from them.  I like their food so far.  

I'm not sure if New Ming's owner is aware of this unethical overcharging behavior by their employee.  If New Ming's owner is not aware of it, then they should have a talk with their employees regarding this matter and find out who's been benefiting from all the overcharged amounts.  10 cents x 100 orders is $10 and my earlier larger orders were overcharged by dollars.  That's some bonus income someone's been benefiting from.
author: Gina W.

description: I love this place! they are soo good and cheap.   its like my cafeteria now.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Cheap lunch alert! 

1 item is $4.50 and that includes rice and chow mein. 2 items is $5.50. 

Is it good? It's alright but how many places in SoMa that are not McDonald's can you eat at for less than $5? Exactly.
author: Carlos A.

description:
If this is New Ming, then I am curious what exactly happened to Old Ming. Has he been shuffled off to a nursing home, or is he that guy who plays the two-string stand-up fiddle in the MUNI station for change? Poor old Ming. How could you? Well, Old Ming couldn't have done any more mediocre job in the kitchen than New Ming. This is standard Chinese take-out food done up for the dinner crowd. And why would anyone come here when Henry' Hunan is just a block away? 

Oh, I have the answer. A break in routine. Y'see, Jamie W. and I always go to Henry's for our Chinese quick fix, but after an evening of non-conformist art at MOMA, a change was in order. So we tried this place just as they were closing. They were rolling up the blinds on the back wall to expose the next day's lunch menu. I don't think they were happy to see us since a silent surliness was palpable in the air. We ordered quickly so as not to amass a tidal wave of resentment from the staff. 

We ordered the $4.95 plate of six Potstickers (see photo). They were fine, just on the nondescript side. The $7.95 General Chicken was on the gelatinous side with the chicken flavor fairly minimal as it tasted a bit packaged (see photo). To their credit, there was lots of it, but it wasn't take-out-box-friendly. The best dish was probably the easiest one for them to prepare, the $7.95 Salt and Pepper Pork Chops, which were delicious with all the chopped chiles and grated peanuts on top (see photo). Is it worth a return visit? Well...I think I hear Henry's Hunan-Style Polish Sausage calling my name. 

FOOD - 3 stars...so-so on everything 'cept the pork chops which they do well 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...generic decor, nothing too inviting but clean 
SERVICE - 2 stars...like I said, surly 
TOTAL - 3 stars...I'll round up but only 'cause I'm worried about Old Ming...WHERE IS HE?
author: Ed U.

description: Absolutely love this location! The food is awesome!It is somewhat of a close location from work, but willing to walk 5 blocks or so. Anyone should try it at least once! This is one of the best chinese food locations in SOMA. The lunch menu is awesome since some selections have it over rice which is my preference. The food portions are about good for the price.
author: Michael S.

description:
I think I'm starting to like Ming's because of the fast service recently and I've found my favorite dish there. Lately I've been going at 12:15-12:30 and there's no lines for the lunch specials. 

Their chow mein and fried rice are still pretty salty. No doubt a lot of their dishes are very oily (just like all the other Chinese fast food places), but if you're a spicy food lover like me, you'll love the Cumin Pork. It's a drier dish, mainly just heavily seasoned pork with bits of of celery bits and cilantro. The downside is that there's not much veggies. I usually just get a side of their mixed veggies (broccoli & cauliflower mix). Their mixed veggies are made pretty well, just steamed and lightly salted. Unless my meat dish is not that salted, then I would get the eggplant or string beans with meat. If you're planning to get their 1-item lunch special ($4.90 after tax), you would have to forgo the veggies. For $6.10 you can get both the Cumin Pork and mixed veggies over rice/fried rice/chow mein. 

For a full tummy, it's hard to find a place that is filling and can be under $5 in this area.
author: Connie C.

description:
This place was really inexpensive and quick, but it's the definition of mediocre.  If you're looking for Chinese fast food, you'll probably like Panda Express more.

I ordered the 2 entree to-go lunch.  I had 1/2 fried rice and 1/2 chow mein, orange chicken, and the Mongolian chicken.  All of the food wasn't so flavorful, but it was incredibly cheap (just about $7).

However, this place is super convenient for lunch!
author: Andrew H.

description:
My go-to quick work lunch. This is cheap, somewhat greasy, yet extremely fulfilling Americanized Chinese food.

You have two options when you walk in: order from the pre-made lunch entrees or order from the menu. If the line is short, the pre-made stuff is pretty good: passable orange/sesame chicken, a nicely done cumin pork, oily but delicious chow mein... the spring rolls are solid too. Sometimes they have more interesting dishes, like Chungqing chicken or eggplant, that also do well if you crave some variety while you eat at your desk.

That all said, I'm pretty sure the nice ladies who work there know me as "the tall white guy who really, really, REALLY likes chow fun noodles with barbecue pork". It's my sustenance, my joy, my reason to stop by. You add a little soy sauce, and a little sriracha to it? BOOM, party in your mouth. Add a couple spring rolls and you're out of there for right under $10. One of the best lunches you can get around the SoMa part of the Financial District.
author: Zach M.

description: We stopped into this restaurant on a night we were going to YBCA for a dance concert. The menu had a variety of interesting and unique options. We tried the salt and pepper squid and the eggplant with chicken and shrimp off of the Chef's specials part of the menu. Both dishes were delicious. The service was friendly and efficient. Definitely a nice find!
author: Emilie R.

description:
Quick and easy lunch combos.  $7 for three combos and $6 for two combos.  I like the half fried rice and steamed rice option.  My favorite has got to be the sweet and sour pork; it is cooked where it is not soggy and not to deep fried.  The portions are huge; I usually have half for my lunch and the rest for dinner.  

The place is big where you can sit down and eat with coworkers.  The lines during the lunch rush hour moves quickly since they have the steamers with already prepared food; panda express style. 

The main difference is, this is legit food.  Its a mom and pops shop that cooks in the back and everything is prepare day of (witness them loading produce in the wee-mornings) I will keep coming here as long as im in the FiDi area.
author: Sandie L.

description: Pretty legit Chinese joint in the middle of downtown San Francisco!!! I eat here for lunch like twice a week and I can say for all the time I've eaten here I like everything except the spicy tripe but yes everything is awesome almost authentic. Almost....
author: Tommy Rainier C.

description:
Go-to place for quick chinese. I find the variety to be great and quality to be pretty solid.

I recommend the rice cake with pork, although sometimes this dish varies from not salty/soy sauce-y enough to just right. 

Place is always clean and warm feeling. I love that they have the self-serve tea/hot water area.
author: Sam R.

description: Very disappointed. Charged me for rice without telling me it was an extra charge and I don't think I even ordered it. Server didn't speak English. Also charged me extra for fried tofu. Not sure why veggies and tofu isn't on the menu for $10 like everything else. Bill was $18 w tip. Rip off but two stars because food was tasty
author: Pete S.

description: Perfect whole in the wall lunch spot in SOMA. Very cheap for the quality. Recommend the tofu and green beans.
author: Anastasia J.

description:
Pretty much your average, fast food Chinese restaurant that is similar to Panda Express. 

I'm tempted to give it 3 stars because the chow mein is better than what you find at PE but, last time I came here I got yelled at by the lady behind the counter for asking for half veggies and half chow mein. Lo and behold, I couldn't do that but, my two other coworkers surprisingly were able to   -_-

Cash only, super cheap ($5 for entree + 1 side), quick. Greasy and not healthy at all but if you come here, you probably already made that guess.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Mediocre chinese food at its best! I've ordered off the menu and I've ordered from the deli style. Both times it was really blah chinese food. Then again, it's dirt cheap and in the FiDi, so can't expect too much.

A lot of their deli food is chicken. I wasn't in the mood for chicken so I got the fried rice, noodles, szechuan eggplant, and salt pepper pork chops. They all were on the same level - bland, oily, and sort of luke warm. I honestly like Lee's Deli more. And that is not saying a lot!

There's nothing on the menu that I would come back for, even if I was just looking for a cheap chinese place. There was no dish that I really enjoyed. Even when I ordered off the menu and got the roast duck rice place - it was so disappointing. They gave me 5 pieces of roast duck that was mostly bone and it was way too salty.
