There are a few similar places around that have an edge over this place for me - Lee's Deli, B & M Mei Sing, and Henry's Hunan.

Too mediocre for me to consider!
author: Junel S.

description:
I always order dinner from this restaurant because their chef has the sense of cooking from taste, smell to presentation especially the timing and freshness.  It's a small place but very clean and pleasant. I live one block away and eat around this area often in Hakkasan, MY China, R&G and others. This restaurant is not Michelin Stared or James Beard Awarded and don't have fancy decorating but it's absolutely the 1st choice for food with great quality and cheaper price especially after they had live fish tank carry many live seafood now.

They have so many good dishes I don't want to mention here one by one but their salt and pepper dish is absolute the best better than R&G. Not oily and thin battered, crispy outside soft inside, always fresh with perfect timing and great taste and great smell and always consistent. Their spicy dish is so authentic Sichuan better than Chili House. Their lobster dishes and live fish dishes are probably the best I have had in the bay area. Their price is the cheapest I have paid compare others.
author: Janet L.

description:
It is REAL Szechuan food.  Not that very salty simple Americanized crap that you get at PF Changs.  If you've been to Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Provence in the actual china, as I have, you'll recognize it right away.  Less salt, more oil, and the ever mysterious smoky-perfumed taste of Szechuan peppercorns.  

This is how they serve it there.  Order something you haven't heard of and enjoy.
author: Jack S.

description: Great food for the price and the staff is pretty friendly. I love coming here and ordering the spicy tendon, flaming chili oil fish, chi qi wings, and other spicy dishes.
author: Yash R.

description: New Ming's is great, whether you order from the counter or from the menu. It is always fast and tasty food. If you order from the counter, everything is still fresh and puts any other chinese lunch counter in the area to shame with how flavorful and fresh the food comes out. I am partial to the fried rice with crispy garlic fried chicken and their eggplant. The noodles are great as well. I've also had noodle soup from the menu that was rich and full of veggies and chicken. It is also all fairly cheap, especially for the neighborhood, and is great for lunch or a later stop on your way to the movies.
author: Michael J.

description: Very friendly service and fast. I loved the chow mein, but sweet and sour was just so so. I did like that it was balanced not to sweet not to sour. The plates are perfect size ala carte so you can order a few and share. The reason they get a 4 is the chow mein and the hot and sour soup cup. I thought she gave me a bowl and told her I only wanted a cup. She said that is the cup just a large cup. Would definitely come back to try out other soups in winter time. Great price for the area.
author: Bryce L.

description:
One of my co-workers microwaved Chinese leftovers for lunch (thanks a lot, Z) and the Pavlovian response was just too much to bear.  A quick Yelp search for cheap Chinese food in the FiDi led me to New Ming's.  I got food to go from the steam table (I know... I know...):  "fried" rice, orange chicken and broccoli beef.  

- "Fried" rice - This is nothing more than white rice with a splash of soy sauce and a few strands of scrambled eggs mixed in.  There was nothing fried about it. 

- Orange chicken - Not bad, but overly crunchy, and a few pieces were actually burned.  The sauce was way too sweet.  I will give them credit for preparing the pieces smaller than most places do - they were truly bite sized.

- Broccoli beef - Totally average steam table broccoli beef.

Overall?  You will probably get better Chinese fast food at Panda Express.  

Now, there were plenty of people in the restaurant eating food that looked SO much better, presumably ordered from the regular menu.  That's probably worth trying some day. 

One thing to note:  they DO accept credit cards, but there is a $10 minimum.  If you don't have cash and don't spend $10, you can still use your card for a $0.75 fee.
author: Jen M.

description: Busy, crowded lunch spot with an amazing 1-3 item special. All of the items look hot and fresh which must be the case because the line didnt stop growing. This time around I gave their wet scrambled egg beef on chow fun a whirl. Wasn't bad the egg gravy was nice and loose it was lacking a little flavor maybe a little saltiness? I walked out of there with my chow fun, a beef n broccoli for my bud & a hot n sour soup for an even $20. New Ming's has my vote for decent affordable lunch in the downtown area.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
While on a business trip to the SOMA area, I wanted a break from convention center / hotel food.  I found some SF Chinatown comfort food, but on Mission Street.  I wouldn't make a special trip to come here, but if you have business in the area, it's worth a visit.  

But, you can't beat it for you local favorites.  This place is decent for the price.

One thing odd for an SF restaurant, they serve some chowmein / chowfun dishes.  However, they are listed as Specials" instead of a "noodles" section.
author: Xiao B.

description:
New Ming's exists for one reason: to serve you cheap, fast, and decidedly (slightly below) average Chinese food.  If you find yourself in the Financial District thinking "I could really go for some Panda Express right now, but there are none around".  Head to New Ming's.  if you find yourself thinking "I have 10 minutes to eat and want some orange chicken" head to New Ming's.

However, if you find yourself thinking "I have time to eat and I want Some really food" don't head to New Ming's.  You can do better (although you probably can't beat the price)
author: Jonathan M.

description: I came here for dinner with my family and the food did not disappoint! We ordered korean fried chicken which was a great balance between sweet and sour, and slightly spicy too. We also got minced pork over noodle along with other vegetable dishes. It was a hot day so we got the milktea too! I definitely recommend this place if you want to try something new in the area.
author: Cheryl L.

description:
just found out they changed the interior, the restaurant seems newer and cleaner now
dont know when they did that but anyways
we tried the sichuan cold noodles / za jiang mian and dan dan noodles,
they were okay, noodles are chewy but the sauce is a bit heavy.
the price is reasonable, around 8 for each noodle plate.
author: Miffy L.

description:
continuing on Chinese food week...
New Ming's is a great lunch spot for take out or to go.  They have simple lunch combos - It's $7 for 3 items or $6 for 2 items.  Portions are generous and the food is not as bland as other places.  Again this isn't healthy for you or anything like that but it beats mcdonalds and also satisfies the chinese food crave.  It specializes in chinese food so less variety than Lee's but I think it's at the same level, which isn't saying much, but at least it's another good option that's close to the office!  Decent quality at good prices makes this a good every day place or good option if you don't have time to pack your lunch in the morning.
author: Bebe W.

description: A no frills spot, but the place is clean and the food is solid. I found the employees nice and efficient.  I would come here again.
author: Nick T.

description: Their porridge and fish and scrambled egg hor fun taste exactly like what I would get back home in Singapore! Amazing find. They also fried up some oyster sauce tofu and kai lan according to my request. It was delicious. My brother got the beef scrambled egg hor fun which was equally good. The zha jiang mian is too salty though. Authentic (Singaporean) Chinese zi char food!
author: Nicola L.

description: Good for a quick lunch, it's set up subway sandwich style for most dishes. You can sit and wait if you order a speciality. Everyone ordered the lunch special and the favorites were the Mongolian chicken, steamed rice, and mushroom chicken....2 item special is about $6.60.
author: Molly S.

description: Kinda bland. Expected more flavors for the price. Interesting seating. Not your typical dining experience for urban. Inner city culture.
author: Shaun G.

description: If you're looking for a simple, delicious Chinese restaurant, this should be your next stop! Prices are very reasonable, ranging from $8-15 for most plates. It was very clean inside and service was quick! I'll be coming back in the future!
author: Diana F.

description:
Authentic stuff! Some Chinese friends took me here and it's so awesome. They're kind and serve really quickly. Not only that but their food is AMAZING. 
Plus after you come once, they recognize you and remember you. And if your not familiar with authentic Chinese food the waitress will help guide you through the menu. 
If you're visiting SF and you want delicious, real Chinese food go here!
author: Maddie A.

description: The food was underwhelming to say the least. I had the Orange Chicken and potstickers. The chicken was hard! It almost felt like I was chewing gum it was so hard! the chicken consisted of little pellets of meat. I swear they were some processed crap out of a freezer bag! The potstickers were ok and saved the meal. This place is definitely not worth a visit! I would have felt better about Panda over this place.
author: Thomas J.

description: The food was made to order and staff very courteous.   Simple flavors and salty with too much cornstarch in the sauces.  Prices very affordable for family a night out.
author: Lisa P.

description:
When we walked into the restaurant, the waitresses that seated us were very warm- the welcomed us with smiles. When we asked for the waitress's opinion on what to eat (because there were a lot of different dishes), she asked us what we liked, our allergies, and if we enjoy spicy food or not. The waitress ordered us pea sprout with garlic sauce, on choy with garlic As, minced pork over noodle, braised tofu with minced chicken and shrimp, and the korean style chicken wings. 

The vegetables that we ordered were a nice light dish for the heavier dishes that they ordered us. Pretty crunchy but too little garlic.

The minced pork over noodle was delicious. The cucumbers that cane with the noodles were very refreshing. The sauce was sweet and the minced pork mixed so well together. Definitely going to order the next time I come back.

The korean wings were almost liek san tung chicken wings but these wings are definitely a lot more meaty. The sauce is thicker, like a glazed chicken wing dish. It had a kick of spiciness that my party enjoyed. The only thing was that the wings arent as crunchy... Maybe they didnt double fry. 

I decided to get their milk tea. It was like a traditional hong kong milk tea. Perfect sweetness. They use evaporated milk that made it different from the ordinary milk tea i often get from boba places. 

All in all, nice and quick service, food was better than i expected, and the pruce was fair co.pared to the other restaurants in downtown.
author: Jolan C.

description: Forget the soup Nazi. This place is the to go box Nazi. I came here for lunch with a group of friends and got my food in a to go container. My friends decided to eat in, so I sat down with them and began to eat. The waiter comes by and demands that I cannot eat in out of a to go box and that I must eat on a plate. He then proceeds to take my box of food away so he could put my food on a plate. I guarantee he took the box back to the sink to wash it out to give to another customer. It is just a box people. I didn't even shout them out for only giving me two items when they charged me for three. Absent the box dilemma, the food is unremarkable greasy Chinese takeout. I am not going back and they can put their box where the sun don't shine.
author: J. W.

description:
Semi-restaurant, semi food-court like lunch plate spot on Mission.  It's cheap, greasy ass chinese food made for american palates.  The kind everyone likes, but doesn't love.  Crispy sesame or orange chicken, plain fried rice and 1 or 2 other dishes - enough to feed a big guy - for under $8.  

If you're looking for organic, fancy, healthy, or anything close - this ain't the place.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Price: 4 stars
Food: 3 stars
Service: 3 stars
Atmosphere: 2.5 stars

Overall: 3 stars + 1 star because there's really nothing better if you're looking for fast food at Panda Express prices but better quality than Panda Express.

Steaming trays of Chinese food under the fiery glow of heat lamps... mmhmm... cheap lunch 6th senses going off!

If you're looking for a quick bite of Chinese food at low prices (relative to the rest of the Financial District in SF) - then you really only have 2 choices if you're in this neighborhood: This place New Ming on Mission St., or B&M (Mei Sing) on 2nd St.

Lunch prices (which go until 5 pm) are about $6.50 to $8.50 for a plate of food. Generous portions akin to other Chinese food places and the taste is decent. You're not going to get your mind blow paying less than $10 for food in SF Financial District, but for its location and price, it deserves 4 stars.

The food itself is pretty generic, or slightly above average. 3'ish stars.

The service is pretty mediocre, but you're paying little more than $5, so you're really only here for food and not service. At dinner, when the horde of people are not as visible, you get much more attentive care. Not surprisingly their prices also go up to about $10-$11 a plate at night.

The atmosphere feels more like a cafe or a fast food joint than a restaurant. Seats are limited during lunch and it gets crowded pretty fast but they do have a basement - which eerily looks and feels like a dungeon.

My opinion is this place is better than B&M (Mei Sing) but Mei Sing does have a better "atmosphere" and interior. If where and what your surroundings feel like matter to you, B&M might be the Chinese place to go.

4 stars because well, there's really no other better Chinese alternative at this low a price in my humble opinion.
author: D K.

description: came in for lunch with a friend because i was craving noodle soup!  ordered at the registered and got a number, and waited about 10 minutes for our dishes - pretty efficient! we got - dan dan noodle, garlic pea sprouts and korean chicken wings.  plus tip cost $40! which is a lot, right, for lunch time chinese? oh welllll. everything was okaaayyyy.  i understand that it's convenient and fast, but really, the quality could be a bit better. dan dan noodle was kinda bland, chicken was a bit too sweet, so the veggies were my fave, but no one should eff that up..! sigh. at least satisfied my chinese food craving for now. but seriously. $40?! ughh.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place is GREAT. When I go for lunch, I always order the spicy beef noodle soup. It really hits the spot. For dinner, I lean towards mapo tofu which goes very well over a bowl of rice. Not always a big fan of tofu, but this is so saucy that I can't pass it up. 

If I'm with a party we usually order fish from the fish tank and it comes out hot with some of spicy sauce every time (which also goes well over rice). Even when I bring my colleagues who are not too big on Chinese food, they still enjoy the spiciness. And don't forget the steamed vegetables! They come out freshly steamed for every order. Cause what's a meal without some veggies?!
author: Gabrielle Q.

description:
You'll notice as you walk up, the outside signage is plain and simple.  You will notice the exact same thing about the inside decor.  When you get your food and take your first bite,  it will become obvious that they're working on a theme.  

The lunch special prices are very reasonable and I had my food in no time.  It's the meat and three of Chinese food... plain and simple.
author: Will L.

description:
decent sichuanish stuff.

had the pork belly thing with rice, it was pretty good.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
It's cheap, affordable good food.

It's close by where I work and within walking distance if you work in the Financial District or SOMA area.

No frills here and it's always solid, good (not great) Chinese Food.

Your money goes a long way here.

Cash only though.
author: A U.

description:
I mean... what do you expect from a "Chinese" restaurant in FiDi? It's basically a Panda Express... so my standards were definitely lowered, give the fact that the menu was very Americanized as it is catered to those who work in FiDi. That's perfectly fine with me, but this isn't really "Chinese" food. 

Anyways, got take out from here the other night. Called to order and the lady was very nice and confirmed everything with me twice just to make sure that she had the right order, which I did appreciate. Went there 15 minutes later, the food was almost all cooked. It was all freshly made since I was basically watching them prepare it in the kitchen. Seeing how much food I ordered and how I struggled with holding everything with my hands, they kindly opened the door for me and wished me a good night. Definitely sweetened my night after an extremely painful day at work. These ladies are so sweet! 

But on to the food.. it's average Americanized Chinese food, given that it's probably more gourmet than others. Since I was ordering for the team, we got the usual Orange Chicken (3 orders), Kung Pao Chicken (1 order), Szechuan Beef (1 order), and Mixed Veggies (2 orders). My favorite out of those dishes was probably the Orange Chicken, though it could've used more sauce. The mixed veggies were nice as they were nicely sauteed with garlic, The portions are pretty generous and prices reasonable. For all that plus 3 large boxes of rice, it was roughly $80, and fed 6 people, with lots of leftovers! I'm pretty sure they have some lunch deals too, so I'll maybe come back if I'm craving "Chinese" food since my options are limited in FiDi.
author: Michelle L.

description: Just looking at the food I can feel my blood clot. I played it safe and ordered shrimp won ton soup. Man did I make a mistake. t basically was salt water with shrimp and iceberg lettuce. You read that right, iceberg lettuce. I even got the bottom of the lettuce (the stem). What I didn't like even more was the shrimp with the brown vein. We all know what that brown stuff is. I am just completely over ordering Chinese food. The only place worst than this is Juhu Beach Club.
author: S. G.

description: For the FiDi / tourist / tech company hybrid area that this place inhabits the pricing is actually really pretty good for something that serves "real" food. 5 bucks for 1 item and side, 6 for 2, 7 for 3. Simple as it gets and consistent with Panda Express pricing in much less expensive places even. And the variety of stuff to choose from is decent. The eggplant and spicy pork were both pretty good. I dunno why it took me so long to try this spot, but I'll be back.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Actually to AU from Martinez, I pick up dinner's to go every couple of weeks and have never paid in cash...for the past few years, they have always taken my debit or credit card.  

I love this place.  Just down the street from my office - and they are always pleasant.  You know how the fast-food orange chicken (think mall food court or Panda) is super breaded, lots of coating and you think, where's the chicken?  Not New Mings!  Their orange chicken is chicken BREAST, lightly coated and it's super delish.  That and a side of chow mein, some spring rolls...I'm good to go!  

Great place.
author: GJ C.

description: Pretty decent take out chinese food that's not super greasy. I liked the winter melon soup and the sweet and sour fish. The restaurant looks kind of like a cafeteria, with big round tables and a counter where you order. But the ladies that took my order were really nice.
author: Sherry L.

description: if you like fat, greasy, disgusting, over-cooked, america-nized fake chinese food, then DON'T COME HERE! because New Ming's is probably the best chinese place in the city. I'm talking about real, authentic, super spicy chinese food! Amazing! Their mini hot pots are just crazy! Their fried calamari are addicting!!! I love probably everything they have! What can be better than after a long hard day to share nice big dinner with friends?!!! They have tapioca milk tea, which is not too sweet, just perfect (can be served cold or hot, as you prefer it). People are really nice and helpful, always suggest new interesting things. Just amazing and must-try place!
author: Asiyat T.

description:
To be perfectly honest, I only order the fried rice, garlic chicken (cumin pork, on occasion), and eggplant and always to-go. I am all for cheap and quick lunches ($6.10 - don't forget your dime!).  I am definitely a fan!

Oh, I'd probably bring cash as New Ming's charges if you use your debt/credit card.
author: Jeanie L.

description:
Fast-check!

Cheap-check! (they have a la carte menu, or you can order off their lunch bar.)

Food = average.  Typical greasy spoon Chinese but plenty to choose from!  Garlic chicken was good, but too much batter/breading for me.  Tofu with green beans was good.  I loved their chow mein/lo mein (ergo noodles.)  Flavors are there. But then again, so is some healthy dosage of grease.  

Their clay pots seem to be popular and I saw them carrying around a fresh dish of shrimp with lobster sauce...so we'll be back! 

Service = self-service.  Water and tea, help yourself.  The rest, pay for it at registers.  Order your food at the counter too.  If you want chopsticks, ask them for, otherwise, they'll just hang you some gwoi-lo forks.  :) 

Decor = circa 1980's table and chair set up with fluorescent lighting.  Oh their menu has English, Chinese and some Korean on it.  (Yet they serve mostly Chinese American and a few Japanese dishes.)  

Seating = plentiful.  While we did not venture downstairs, there appears to be more seating down there too.

Overall, I'll come back here for a quick lunch.
author: Fannie S.

description: Its fast and cheap, but the food wasn't anything special. Feels like a more Chinese panda express
author: Anthony W.

description: The food is really reasonably price and decent.
author: Sofya T.

description:
Try the wontons in chili sauce, you will not be disappointed. I was a BIT disappointed in the plain tasting but excellently chewy "pork with rice cakes". Thanks to fellow Yelpers I am finding the dishes which shine. 
Keep on describing the good stuff, experts, and we will try them!
author: Nan L.

description: So I read reviews on yelp and I decided that I would go here and try some chow mein and General's chicken for lunch via the lunch special that they advertise. I went in around 2 and the sign was up outside advertising the lunch special and the prices. When I went in I got ignored for about 5 min. When I was about to leave the lady asked me what I wanted, I told her the lunch special and she told me that they didnt have any more lunch special food and that I could order a rice plate. If the lunch special was over why have the sign up outside? What is the point? Anyways, because of the rude service I left and went to subway.
author: Renee F.

description: For a cheap, hot lunch you can't beat New Mings.  Good chinese food in the FiDi.  It always satisfies my chinese food craving without flipping my stomach upside down.
author: Donna R.

description:
Cons:
- Only accept cash under 10 bucks.
- The food here is "soggy" and slimy - EVEN the fried rice.  My dish tasted like "typical" Chinese food that was sprayed down with a spray bottle.  I almost didn't even eat it.
- Rice and 2 items cost 6.10, you would be better off going to Panda Express.

If you have to go here I would recommend you order something that's not sitting behind the counter "ready to eat" (don't do the rice and two item).  The food I had was after the lunch rush and was probably not their "best" (I assume).  Order something off the menu that they need to cook fresh.
author: Jose P.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. Order off the menu! 
My Chinese food lunch spot. 
A few of my favs are:
Singapore style vermicelli noodles is one of the best items here. The black pepper beef chow udon is a hit or miss. One day it can be super yummy and another day it will be a plate of black pepper. Cant ever go wrong with beef chow fun.
Call in orders if you are in a hurry or have a short lunch break. During peak times it might take a while for your food to come up.
author: Linda L.

description: For the price, I wouldn't complain. No it's definitely not the best Chinese food I've had but the quality and portions are good for the price I'm paying. Especially in the Financial District. The lunch $7 Combo for 3 items and chow mein is great. I do wish there was more veggies in their food though.
author: Vi T.

description: Good and fresh after chipping away at the staff I finally soften them up and they remember me now and smile laking of variety but foot is great
author: Mike J.

description: everyday place for lunch! their food is soooo good !!! always have plenty of seatings even the busiest time. Staff are super nice and helpful. I would love to go there every single day because they have so many options, and if you are wiling to try, there are very authentic food there. Don't stick with the orange chicken and chow main, it will surprise you!
author: Yining Z.

description: 3 stars is fair.  Got cashew chicken rice plate and thought it was good, but not great.  didn't make me feel bad after, which is a plus.  good amount of food.  nice staff, clean place.  worth another shot to see how their steam tray stuff is.  $7.10
author: Marc S.

description:
For over 160 years, San Franciscans (or SasaFrassases as absolutely nobody calls them), have struggled to keep up with the daily arms race that is the downtown food scene. Every sunrise brings with it the renewed responsibility to hunt down better, healthier, or just plain different choices, crawling through offshoot alleys, hidden pop up restaurants, and even running after the occasional runaway food truck. 

I'd like to think this daily chore has annealed and readied us for life's more pressing challenges. When the big one hits, knowing about that secret getaway alley might come in handy. But mostly it's annoying.  It's nice to throw your hands up every once in a while, fall backwards, and let the hot, greasy wave of mediocre Chinese food carry you back to simpler times.  I hit that wall today, and took a short, contemplative walk to New Ming's. 

In all honesty, I thought the food was pretty good. No matter what some folks say, this is certainly better than, say, Panda Express, or some other run of the mill fast food Chinese joint. Any place placarded with sheets of paper announcing daily specials in both chicken scratch English and Mandarin gets bonus points for authenticity.  That said, it's solidly middle of the road, so don't come expecting even slightly haute cuisine. It's not as fancy or adventurous as Fang, for instance. It's a solid, blue collar place, getting its work done without offense or frills. Those with cholesterol or heart issues (or hearts, for that matter) should avoid coming here on a regular basis, but it's a good choice on those days when the craving hits.  Thanks for the breather, New Ming's! 3 to 3.5 stars.
author: Julio A.

description: Damn I love this place. The lunch special includes 2 items with rice or noodles for $6!! Yeah it's not spa food but oh so tasty. The lunch special is only until 2 or if they run out.
author: R D.

description: As you can see from many other reviews they do have steam trays full of food ready for those on the go during the lunch craze, do yourself a favor and order something on the menu, it will be made fast and fresh. If you're craving some hangover soup noodles go with the dan dan noodles if you can hang with the heat, you will be blowing the sh*t out of you nose or the house won ton noodle soup is legit too if your not into fire water.
author: Ryan C.

description:
We stopped in for dinner after a happy hour that ran a little too late, and Ming's hit the spot.  I'm leaning toward a 3.5 rating, but in this case I'll round up to four. 

We ordered the salt and pepper squid, sezchuan tofu and eggplant, garlic spinach, seafood fried rice, mongolian beef, and huge amounts of hot tea.  Everything was all really tasty, and the people working were really sweet.  

I think I'll be in for lunch and some boba soon.
author: Dana S.

description:
New Ming's is a great place to get lunch if you work in San Francisco. My office is on Second Street, and I love the ten minute walk over to New Ming's.

For less than $7, you can get a plate of food with two main dishes and a side. Choices of main dishes include items like sesame chicken, eggplant, mixed vegetables, black pepper chicken. The side dish included is either fried rice, steamed rice or chow mein. They also offer pretty sizable portions of food, so you feel like you got your money's worth.

New Ming's gets 4 stars for meeting my expectations of what I want out of a workday lunch: quick, cheap and delicious.
author: Jen B.

description:
This place is great for cheap/decent Chinese food almost buffet style. There are many entrees to choose from other than what's displayed. The portions are much larger when you take to go, but the regular plate is not too shabby. 

I ordered chow mein with string beans/tofu and orange chicken for about $6.20. There are a lot of servers helping out so they are pretty fast and efficient. The good thing about this place is they have a lot of seating, extra tables downstairs. The tables downstairs make me feel like I'm sitting at those chinese mafia tables, playing poker or mahjong. haha! It's a bit sketchy but it will do. 

I won't say that this will be the "best" chinese food you will ever have. But it will fill you up if you're starving and looking for a fast meal.
3.5 stars overall!
author: Karen L.

description: The best Chinese comfort food in the city. The chefs special menu is what my grandmother used to cook back home. This place is a winner
author: Ron C.

description:
I think New Ming's does not deserve the drubbing it gets on Yelp.  If you want to get good food at New Ming's, you need to venture away from the Americanized chicken/beef combos on the menu and stay away from the ready made steam table.  Instead, be a little adventurous.  Sure, it might cost you $10 instead of $5 for lunch but it is much more satisfying and tasty.

Came here with a group of 4 guys and we ordered a mix of standard Chinese fast food and some other more interesting stuff.

 - pig intestine and fried tofu clay pot
 - pickled veg and lamb clay pot
 - malaysian chow fun noodles
 - pepper chicken rice plate
 - pot stickers

Needless to say for me, the more interesting clay pots were the stars.  The pig intestines were chewy and spicy, nicely offset by the fried tofu.  The pickled veg gave a nice unusual sour taste to the lamb soup (common for Thai food but I've never had it in Chinese before).

The other dishes were also done well but nothing exceptional.  I wasn't very impressed by the Malaysian chow fun.  The potstickers were a miss too (why is it everyone always wants potstickers?  resulting in restaurants putting it on the menu even though they aren't good?).

The five of us weren't even able to finish all the food (and no, not just because it was weird) and it only came out to $13/person including tax and tip.
author: Jean K.

description:
I am still finding my way through the menu even though I've probably had lunch here a half dozen times in the last year. (If I am craving Chinese food and in a tearing rush I'll steam table - eggplant, green beans, fresh mushroom chicken are faves.) 

BBQ Pork Wonton soup - just average I thought, not much better than Lee's.

Minced pork with rice cake - Delicious! A tiny bit stingy on the pork but still really good. The rice cakes were the perfect texture.

Spicy beef noodle soup - Holy smokes! Spicy! This soup had a nice layer of red chili oil on top. The spice doesn't linger though and the broth was rich and peppery. Yum! I upped my star rating a half star for this alone. Super warming on a chilly day. Make yourself a napkin bib - soup noodles in chili oil = splatter!
author: Kiely H.

description: We came in a half hour before closing, the staff was having a meal, and yet the service was super fast, everyone was really nice, and the food was delicious.
author: Erika S.

description:
Mings, for when you want cheap decent Chinese food & a lot of it.

Half Fried Rice, Half Noodle, Sesame Chicken & Mixed Veggies for about $6. That's my go to meal. I figure the veggies make it a little healthier. I've only ordered off the steam tray and really haven't tried many dishes (the aforementioned Sesame Chicken, Orange Chicken, Beef w/ Broccoli & some Spicy Eggplant dish). Everything I have tried has been pretty good though.

For the whiners whining about not getting enough soy sauce or hot mustard just squeeze some cock sauce I mean Sriracha on your food and you won't need any damn soy sauce or mustard to mask the cheap Chinese flavor. It's right next to the register when you pay waiting for you!

Also to comment on service, everyone from the food scooper lady to the money taker lady seems friendly to me.

Dammit, now I'm hungry.
author: Noah K.

description: Great quality / price ratio. Choice of dishes is really big. Great place for quick lunch.
author: Radoslaw D.

description:
"Is there an Old Ming's??"

Thisis more of a 2.5 star review.  Chinese fast food. While the quality and taste are not amazing they're definitely A-OK. Its also a reasonable value, and its fast.  New Ming's is as no frills as they come, which is great because it really does feel like they pass the savings on to you.  Like any food establishment - they could stand having more healthier choices, but really i have no complaints.
author: Oleg H.

description: This place is TERRIBLE! The kitchen was so backed up that I was late getting back to work on my lunch. I didn't even get my food after I paid for it! I had to go somewhere else and forfeit my money I paid! People were waiting 20, 25 even 30 minutes for their food....ridiculous! Never going there again.......
author: Rebecca S.

description: Growing up with an Asian mother, this is as close as you can get to Chinese cooking.  It's quick and delish!
author: Tammy C.

description:
Fast and cheap!!!
Food is decent/ edible. The (fried) garlic chicken is addictive.
Order items from the food warmer trays or made to order from the menu board.

For newbies: Water and hot tea are self-service, at left side of counter.

This place is much cleaner than their old tiny hole-in-the-wall location that closed in 2008. Note that if the main dining room is full, there's a downstairs area with more tables also.
author: Luis C.

description: Fantastic for the price. I usually don't ask too much of places like this. They're great for a quick delicious and incredibly satisfying meal and that's the standard I'll hold them to. I'm not expecting outstanding. The lunch special is a great deal (noodles, and two items for $6.50) and their menu items are pretty good. It will totally satisfy your chinese food craving!
author: Sam W.

description:
portion was relatively small
spicy duck was good
minced tofu was good
vegiie pot was ok
couples lung was good
author: Diane W.

description:
This is starting to become my go-to place in the area for lunch, since so many food places around here charge so much. Maybe I'm still not used to SF prices still. But it's a good amount of food on your plate, there's a good variety of offerings, and everything at least tastes fairly good. 

They do get some points off in my book because  some of the fried items are a bit too breaded, and if you come after the lunch rush they kind of put multiple items on the same pan and there's very little left. I wouldn't deviate far from the Chinese [American] items. Their lumpia looks a bit off and their drinks aren't the best. 

But in the end the food is good for the price and they don't have a lot of sass...maybe even friendly at times which is different and a huge plus when it comes to Chinese restaurants.
author: Justin C.

description:
I preferred Ming's when it was open on 2nd Street; however, New Ming's has filled the void that its predecessor has left behind.  Their only good chicken dish is the Sesame Chicken, which has a bit of a nutty flavor to it.  Their chow mein is prepared with lo mein noodles.

Be forewarned: if you ask for half chow-mein and half-rice, they will literally serve you half a portion of each (leaving a huge gap in the container) and then complain about you for the rest of the time you're in line.  They will look at you with eyes that tell you you're the cheapest person on the planet.

Once you get over that humiliation, you'll be fine.  Enjoy!  :-P
author: Jonathan R.

description: Went to New Ming's in SOMA for the first time and got a great deal for a two-item lunch for $6.10.  Tried the Sesame Chicken and the Tofu with string beans.  Service is fast and space to sit if you want.
author: Lon H.

description: $6.10 lunch special which entails fried rice or noodles with 2 sides. There's a couple choices to choose from. I especially enjoy the fried garlic chicken which is crunchy, but not oily. If you're not into that, they also have many types of noodles, fried rice and protein dishes in their menu you can choose from
author: Connie M.

description:
Worst Xiao Long Bao I've ever had in my whole life. They are seriously worse than the frozen ones you buy from Ranch99. They look like they were wrapped by a 5 year old and at almost $1 a piece, it's definitely not worth it. The skin is tough and thick with no elasticity. There's absolutely no soup inside. The stuffing tasted like frozen meatballs you buy from Costco by the pound.

Other dishes I've tried are ok, e.g., scrambled eggs with shrimps on flat rice noodles, though not as substantial as the lower priced B&M. The E-Fu noodle's under-cooked. I would most likely not go back again. If I do, I'd be trying out the Chef Specialties which look a bit Taiwanese/Shanghainese.

Very disappointing overall.
author: DANIEL T.

description: New Ming's is a great place for family dinners. Their Black Pepper Beef is to die for and the customer service was outstanding. The Three Peppered Chicken goes really well with rice along with some Mapo Tofu. If you want inexpensive authentic family style Chinese dinner, this is the place to go.
author: Max M.

description:
While it's not the best or most authentic Chinese food it's wayyyyyyy better than Panda express while giving you panda express-ish prices. 

They make a mean shrimp fried rice for $6. That thing had like 10-12 shrimps in there!
author: Earl G.

description: New Ming's is pretty much the default place to go for me and my co-workers when we're working late in the financial district. It's walking distance to us and they are super fast with their orders. I absolutely LOVE their eggplant with pork dish -- even though it's on the oily side. It is what I order almost every single time with a side of rice. I tried their wonton soup once and it wasn't that great. Prices are really affordable and they open late -- so nothing to complain about! Except every time I go late they run out of boba but then I tried their milk tea on its own and it wasn't that great to begin with.
author: Konnie H.

description:
Had lunch there today with some co workers. 
I ordered salted fish with chicken fried rice and preserved egg with pork porridge.  I say it was great for the price and would def be back for lunch again.
Giving it 3 stars for being cheap eats and so close to work:)
author: Teens F.

description:
Food is probably 3 to 4 stars, but the price definitely puts it up closer to 4+! I like to get the chicken - garlic, orange, and sesame - all are amazing!

They don't take card unless you order over $10 I think, so make sure you bring cash. Only $6.10 exactly for a two choice plate ;-)
author: Brad Y.

description:
Came to this restaurant because my boss recommended it boy was I surprised at how good it is. 

As a Chinese-American, I can appreciate both American styled Chinese food and Legit Chinese food that only Chinese people eat. This place has both of those areas covered.

I ordered mongolian beef over rice, it was extremely tasty, the veges were fresh looking and tested fresh not soggy. The meat was really tender and well cooked and the rice was soft and a bit sticky. 

The portion is great and comes at a price of $6.50. Honestly you can not get a better deal than this. If you are a young asian-american working professional who can appreciate good, clean tasting american-chinese food. this is your spot to go.

p.s. make sure to get the hot chili oil if you are into spicy. man that is a killer sauce!
author: Alan L.

description:
Went here with a bunch of friends for lunch.

Went in line and ordered fried rice, vegetables, and cumin pork.

Not as greasy as I expected for Chinese food. I would return for lunch because rice with two items cost only 6.50. Also, bring cash, they charge extra for credit cards.
author: John N.

description:
Good cheap fast chinese food

You can't go wrong with this place....rice and two items is like $6.50, three items is $7.50 or something like that.

It's cafeteria inside, there's extra seating in the basement

Don't expect much service past the cash register. You're there to eat your good cheap food and get out. It's a downtown lunch spot. 

Food is always fresh, well cooked they have a good range of basic and more...traditional chinese dishes.
author: Leo V.

description:
Old Man Ming brings his old world style slimy scrambled eggs and rice dish for us foolish Americans to enjoy. What's not to love about Ming's? You can choose to eat on the ground floor or downstairs in Mr. Ming's dungeon. MMM mmm mmm. Try the XO Style chicken fried rice that's pretty decent too. Don't listen to the people who only gave this place 1 or 2 stars they just don't understand the love Mister Ming puts into his cooking. I bet they all ordered off the steam tray as well. Never do that... just walk right up to the register and get something off the menu. The fresher the better. 

I'll see you soon Mr. Ming!
author: kArlos A.
Stan C.

description: Went here for a quick workday lunch.  I was feeling under the weather so I was craving hot and sour soup.  They do a lunch special where its a Panda Express style line of entrees in chafing dishes that you get to choose from.  All the food looked tasty, and the line moved fast.  You can also order from the full menu.  There's plenty of extra seating in the basement, which I didn't even know existed until I went in.  This place is a great affordable quick and tasty lunch option.
author: Steven Z.

description:
I'm a sucker for salty, greasy chinese food, so that's a caveat on my review. 

I ran in today, needing something fast. For a mere $4.50 (still sub $5 after tax), I exited in less than two minutes with rice and tofu with string beans. 

The rice was white and boring (I could have gotten something more exciting like fried rice or chow mein, but I didn't want a gigantic meal). The tofu and string beans were good. Flavorful, a little kick, the tofu was chewy not mushy, and the beans still had a lil crunch in 'em. 

I'll be back.
author: Allison S.

description:
The bf texted me ten minutes before noon asking if I wanted to meet up for lunch.  Sure!  
Chipotle sounded good but the line was out the door.  New Ming's it was!  

I enjoyed a one item combo plate with half chow mien / fried rice and Orange chicken.  It was some of the best chow mien I've had in recent memory.  The bf had a two item plate and was stuffed when he was done.  

1 - 1 item combo
1 - 2 item combo
2 - Bottled sodas

$17.15 

I'll be back...
author: Sofia H.

description:
Nice and clean and modern interior. The lunch specials ($5-$7) are tasty and a great deal!

Not a fancy place, but great for a quick Chinese food lunch. They seem to have a good variety of selections on the menu.
author: James W.

description:
Haters!  New Ming's Haters!  Maybe it's because my parents used to own a "steam tray" restaurant (as Brad P. refers to it - to clarify, I said steam table. Not that steam table makes more sense but that's what I grew up knowing it as.)...or because I spent many a weekend working at our "steam tray" restaurant, but I do have a soft spot for independently, owned (aka non-Panda Express) fast-food Chinese restaurants.  There it is, that's my bias.

I haven't had a chance to have any of the 2-item/3-item specials, but on cold days, I head across the street (dodging cars) to get some won ton noodle soup.  Comfort food!  Nothing will ever be as good as Mom's, but the egg noodles, broth, won tons and char-seu hit the spot.  I also hear the rice porridge is good too!  I'll be heading back to try some items for the "steam tray" soon...
author: Wendy L.

description:
For good, fast Chinese food ready to go when you get there, Mings is the place to go. In the SOMA, there are quite a few places to get Chinese food, but very few of them are ready to go when you get there (unless you count the Lees' Chain, which in my opinion does not have that good food). This is basically a nicer version of Panda Express which is perfect for the area its located in. Should you want something they're not serving, you can always order something off their extensive menu, though you will have to wait a bit for it should you do that. My personal favorite items to get are the Cumin Pork and the Sesame Chicken, though every now and then I change it up and try something different.

If you're looking for top quality Chinese food and don't mind waiting for it, go to one of the many other Chinese restaurants around this area. But if you want something fast and ready to go that will have you in and out in mere minutes, Mings is the place to go!
author: Gajan K.

description:
I come to New Ming's when I need to satisfy my Chinese food cravings and I rarely am disappointed with the food I get here. It's definitely not a 5 star dining establishment nor do they try to pretend like they are. So if you're expecting some fine ass Chinese cuisine, don't come here (go to R&G!) It is a good and quick place to grab lunch. They have a lot of options in their hot table (string bean and tofu is my fav!) and 2 items with your choice of fried rice/white rice/chow mein for $6 is pretty worth it. I've also ordered the watery egg and shrimp over rice, the curry chicken over rice, different types of jooks for those sick days, and noodle soup for those hungover days and I felt they were all pretty good. 

However, I'm not gonna lie. I have suffered from msg coma a few times after eating here. I'm still a fan of this place.
author: Anita L.

description:
My "go to" restaurant for a quiet night at home Chinese food. They don't deliver, so you have to fight the Third Street traffic, and dodge the Mission Street Parking maids, but the food is worth it.

Call your order in, and be there in 10 minutes or less to pick it up. Always fresh and hot. we lived at the Paramount across the street for a year, and by the time we ordered, took the elevator down from the 34th floor and crossed the street, the food was ready. Now we are out in Mission Bay, but it's still worth the 10 minute drive to get this food.

Have not had a disappointing meal choice from them. Pepper beef or chicken, Mongolian lamb, all very good, and the prices are very reasonable.

Not fancy to eat in, but for home take out, a great place to go.
author: Terry L.

description:
=New Mings Restaurant=

San Francisco always has great chef's behind the food line. If you don't like sitting next to strangers, then don't come here because that's what is going to happen if you dine in. They have a few round tables where you need to sit caferteria style with strangers. The food line was pretty tasty! I ordered food in the display line, such has braised string beans, garlic fried chicken pieces, and chow mein. The chow mein wasn't anything spectacular, but the fried chicken pieces has the crispyness, and tenderness that you won't find in a good chicken! Not too much batter either, and not stringy. Get a side of sweet and sour and dip in there for the tangyness of the sauce with the crispyness of the chicken.

The braised beans could use more spice, but everything was good! really cheap too, under $7 bucks you get a meal and it's a good size helping
author: Christopher J.

description: I love this place. Food is fresh, the price is just right... and is old school enough so I don't have to endure an over trendy experience. I've been here several times since my first visit and it appears there are quite a few regulars... always a good sign.
author: Victor S.

description:
This is exactly what is expect from a cheap Chinese food restaurant sandwiched between a few 7-11s and Starbucks on mission street. 

Food comes up in 1 minute.  A plate of noodles is $7.95, they're greasy, the pork is tough, the shrimp are tiny and the waitress yells at full volume to the back of the kitchen of you have a question.

Definitely not for anything more than sustenance or hangover cures or satisfying a craving for grease and msg... Which is what I had today and I'm a satisfied customer.
author: Charley R.

description:
I have to admit that I've eaten at New Mings only once. After a disappointing meal at Mels down the street on Mission I wanted to detox with some white rice and  freshly steamed vegetables. 

This place is always busy when i pass by. it is part buffet and part order-what-you-want from the vast menu. It impressed me as an expensive place to go with fresh Chinese dishes. Next time I go I want to try the seafood porridge and the Taro drink.

They even had Mexican Tamarind soda in the fridge. 

Never been to Old Ming's but New Ming's get four stars today!
author: Mikes M.

description:
This place is solidly mediocre.  My string beans and tofu wasn't bad, and the spicy chicken brought the heat.

It's good to have a list of close-to-office sub $5 lunch places, and I'll add this one to it.  But, I can't see myself there more than once every few weeks.
author: Eric S.

description: Average Chinese food for lower than average prices. Don't have much else to say that hasn't been said.
author: Mi M.

description:
[Reviewed by K]

Average Chinese food at affordable (for SOMA) prices, fast service.

Granted, you aren't going to get a Thomas Keller meal here, but where else can you eat a sit-down meal in SOMA for $7? We normally order the spicy soup noodle dish on the menu, which is filling and cheap.

If you're hankering for cheap Chinese in SOMA after regular 9-5 hours, this would be your spot.

They also have boba milk tea. Mediocre in quality, but it does quench the craving.
author: Kel S.

description:
Pretty tasty, very affordable price for such a quality. 
They have food which suitable for American taste of Chinese, also some pretty spicy flavor for Chinese.

It's pretty crowd in here so you can totally tell its tasty and popular around here. 
Specially I do recommend this for student in AAU, it's near to school, it's affordable and it's a grab and go choice.
author: Gavin T.

description: A Panda Express by any other name...  Well, this place is basically an upgraded Panda Express, at least their lunch menu.  Food was ok, not great.  I got veggies and tofu, which admittedly might have been a mistake.  They're pretty fast, which is nice.
author: Allen C.

description:
New Ming's may be overlooked for its location between New Montgomery and 3rd Street; along this strip of Mission Street are a lot of ritzy eateries catering to the affluent crowd. What are the frugal diners supposed to do around here besides going to the tried-and-true franchises?

Well, go to New Ming's for some reasonably-priced family-style Chinese food. Sure, the atmosphere is quite lax/simple for this part of town, but it's a welcome respite in the midst of everything else. The food is basic American-Chinese food, but the service is wonderful once they warm up to you.

Walk right on in, and you may probably wonder if you should just seat yourself or walk up to the counter to order (like at McDonald's). You can do either; generally, when I go here I walk up to the counter and order and just tell them that we're eating-in.

I've been here several times now after returning from the gym; the staff recognizes me and my s.o. now and they always greet us with great service. They were even patient with us once when the rain was pouring down hard outside and we moved ourselves to a different table to avoid the draft that was coming in through the door.

Overall, we go to New Ming's for the service, atmosphere, and reasonable prices. The food reminds me of home, but it's also basic/standard for most Chinese places I've tried in the city. Nonetheless, the atmosphere is more inviting to all customers than in some other places.
author: Helene K.

description:
Can't argue with the price...but as someone who doesn't like vinegar, there's little on their steam table that I can handle. Some previous reviews refer to "something's that just not right". It's VINEGAR! Honestly, the quality of the food is very good, 'cept for the vinegar. I've tried about 6 dishes plus the chow mein and rice, and items such as the Orange Chicken are cooked very well...and then comes the vinegar.

OK...so I don't like vinegar...you can tell. But if it were toned-down a bit, I'd have to say how much I really enjoy eating here.
author: Scot B.

description:
Is there anything not to love at New Ming's? $5.50 for a two item combo and I can usually save half for later. They have porridge which I think only one other place in fidi offers it. 

Sesame chicken is like panda express's orange chicken and it is my favorite dish there. Sometimes I would order a kitchen item if I don't feel like ordering food from the bucket. 

Cheaper than a McDonald's meal and fast service, the only reason I'm giving it a four stars it becasue I believe they use MSG...but oh well, I would be shock if they didn't use MSG since they taste so good!!

$10 minimum for credit card so have some cash on you.
author: Maggie C.

description: I had their dan dan noodles and it's the first time i've had them in years so I was pleasantly surprised that they were as good a dish as i remember. this place was also conveniently open for a latish 9pm dinner and within a block of the museum we'd gone to see.
author: Miri R.

description:
Decent Chinese food at good prices. It's very cheap considering that it's located downtown. The service is very quick. The chicken and beef tastes alright. The beef isn't chewy and the chicken is actually soft. It's got a leg up on a lot of other Chinese places. 

Beware of $10 min credit card charge.
author: Steven B.

description: I've studiously avoided New Ming's despite work proximity.  Two of my co-workers insist that New Ming's is perfectly delicious if you stay away from the steam tray.  I've long doubted them, but I decided to humor them anyway and take the plunge.  Even though I took great care to avoid the steam tray, the food still sucked and I was $7 in the hole.  Thanks, guys!  I'll stick to my yuppie, organic food, thank you very much.
author: Laurence W.

description:
I changed jobs earlier this year and my new office is about a block farther away and north of Market St. now. However, the food at New Ming's is enough of a draw where I am able to overcome the psychological barrier of the "lunchtime radius."

A recent addition to New Ming's steam table is Cumin Pork. Love it!  I've also been meaning to try their other addition, Tea Smoked Duck. Would love to hear a review if anyone has had it. I was there this afternoon, but they weren't offering the duck.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: I am a very frequent Chinese food eater  and have been accused of being a Chinese man stuck in a white-guy's body! With that as an intro, lets discuss New Ming's. After ordering off the "pick three items" buffet for a few months, I noticed the Chinese patrons lining up to the left, ordering off a menu and having the food delivered to their tables. So, I decided to give it a shot. WOW!!! How shocking to discover that this hole-in-the-wall, buffet-style restaurant is hiding one of the top 3 or 4 Chinese restaurants in SF! The food is outrageously good. And if you have the stomach for it, it is also the best spicy/hot Chinese food this side of Z&Y Lounge (without needing to schlep to C-Town for those of us stuck in SOMA). I have been numerous times with Chinese friends who are equally shocked. The fish and tofu in spicy sauce, the hot pots, the won-tons, EVERYTHING is sensational. Their chicken wings are also among the best (although chopped up into way too small pieces!). The only disappointment has been the stir-fried pork belly, which having ordered it twice, is not what is typically considered port-belly...it is lining or tripe...more like intestine. Tasty, but a bit gamier than I had expected. Otherwise, you can not go wrong. They recently installed a fish tank to display my future dinners....and I hope they don't go too upscale. In the meantime, though, it is an at-least 1X week stop for me. The heat can be intense, but as good spicy food goes, it does not last....Give New Mings a try...you will not be disappointed.
author: Brian B.

description:
Standard San Francisco buffet style cheap-o Chinese restaurant. Place was relatively clean, though eating downstairs was reminiscent of eating in a bunker as there are no windows.

$6.00 for two choices including rice or noodles = OK in my book. Salt and pepper pork chops were tasty. 

You can't go wrong.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Now this is strictly for the Black Milk Bubble Tea they serve here as I have not had the food yet. 

Bleah. Is that a word? Yeah, that's what I'd describe it as. I should have known to head for the door when I ordered a bubble tea and the woman takes a colander from the sink behind her and fishes out the pearls. Strike one. And then she opens up a can of condensed milk. Strike 2. Drink was luke warm. Strike 3. 

While the tapioca pearls itself were fantastic and soft, the actual drink itself left much to be desired. It was far too sweet and did not have enough tea. I drink sweet tea and desire my own weight in sugar most days and even I thought the tea was too sweet. I need a Joy Yee's in this city.
author: Jessica K.

description:
This is your typical Chinese fast food restaurant. They have the standard three item combo deli set up. I prefer this place over the more popular B&M a few blocks away. They use less oil and MSG so I would only need two cups of coffee in the afternoon.  It's been awhile but I used to come here once a week. 

Items I would normally order: 

1. Fried fish with cream corn over rice.
2. Chicken string beans with black bean sauce. 
3. Combination clear noodle with cabbage. 

Tip: They have a separate line if you're not ordering the deli combos. AT&T service sucks here.
author: James W.

description: Their Thai style chow fun is the BOMB!!!  This is probably one of my favorite dishes!!  I can't seem to order the same flavor anywhere else, and their portions are huge for such a cheap price!  It's definitely a great spot for cheap Chinese food lunch!
author: Nancy S.

description:
I don't see what everyone complains about when it comes to this place. Come on, did you really expect it to be Zagat-worthy? Anyways, I find this place pretty good, especially after walking around for a couple hours and needing some quick grub and a place to sit.

My friend and I got the beef chow fun, beef fried rice, and the red chili oil wontons. The chow fun was good, and the beef itself was super tender. The fried rice was OK. A little bland, but definitely not disgusting. And the wontons, they were delicious! I've never had anything like them, but will come back here just for them.
author: Roy J.

description: Killing it on take-out but don't love the buffet or dining in. I get the shrimp fried rice and the mixed veggies. Try it and I swear you won't be disappointed.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Wow, this place is pretty terrible.  Came here one night because we wanted to try something new.  The ordering method was a bit weird, but that's fine.  We ordered "3 cups chicken" and a beef chow fun dish.  The "3 cups chicken" taste nothing like the ones I know from LA or Taiwan, not even close.  It was just a mush of bland soy-sauced stir fry chicken.  The beef chow fun was ok, but nothing to call home about.

Considering these 2 dishes plus sodas cost us about $15-16/person at the end, I'm definitely NOT coming back here.
author: Kryzak K.

description: They have raised their prices too much and their food is all fatty and greasy. The cashier is always rude! I called to place an order for pick up. When I came to pick up, I told them I don't need a bag as I am trying to save the environment. The cashier told me with a big fat attitude to mention no bag the next time I call if I don't want a bag! Then she talked to the other lady in front in their language, giving me "the look" of rudeness, obviously talking about me. RUDE people!!! I will never come back to this place.
author: Mich G.

description:
They totally lost a customer today forever. I order Kong Pao Chicken with rice to go. I got a call from my boss and said I could take a whole hour break, so I decided to eat it there.  I Could not finish all the food, I went and ask for a to go box. " you got to pay .50 per box cause you alreaady got one when we gave you the food" I go like, Are you kidding me? You cant give me a box. Why would i take the big container when I have 1/2 left.  I come here eveery other week, and still she did not give me a box. forget it, Im not coming here ever, ever, Keep your boxes with you.
Also the people working here have a really awfull attittude.
author: Jvan N.

description:
I came here with a coworker and she's been here many times. First I got my lunch paid for so that's a plus.
I got chowmein, mongolian chicken, and broccoli w/beef. 
The beef was only alright but the rest was very tasty and well cooked. There's even some seating downstairs! I had no idea! It seems a lil creepy when you walk down the stairs but it has nice tables and people come by to ask to take your plate, another plus.
Good chinese and a nice place to sit. Oh and good prices :)
I freakin love chinese...so if you want a quick lunch, go to New Mings.
author: Lana K.

description:
New Ming's is a great lunch time spot for great Chinese food at a reasonable price.  My only beef with them is that they are super stingy on the soy sauce and stare at you like they might choke you out if you have the audacity to ask for a 2nd packet.

Veteran tip: Take your to go tray to one of the tables, and douse your fried rice with one of the Kikkoman bottles on the tables for customers eating at the restaurant.  Move quickly though... you will get smacked in the back of the head if you act too slowly!
author: Charles C.

description:
It's CHEAP, it's FAST, and they have Tapioca Milk Tea!!!

I go here at least once a month and usually get the same thing; fried rice with orange chicken and tapioca milk tea.  Let's face it, it's no gourmet Chinese food, but you get for what you pay for; decent food.  They have plenty of dishes to choose from; tofu, chicken, beef, fish and veggie; ingredients always seem fresh and tasty!
author: Celeste M.

description: They make best garlic chicken. Gonna come back again.
author: William I.

description:
I gotta say, I used to come here a whole lot more frequently back before they upped their prices, stopped offering delivery, and stopped serving rice plates, won ton, porrige and udon after 5. (Alright, so I can understand the rice plates, but why the won ton?) 

If you can make it in time for the lunch combos, rice plates ect. or if you're grabbing some specialty noodles, you're in for a massive bargain. If you're getting some dinner items, a lot of them are really tasty even if they are loaded with sodium and MSG. 

I probably would have given New Ming's 4 stars, but I guess I'm a little spoiled from back when things were cheaper and more readily available. If you do decide to stop by, you must try their basil chicken and pumpking rice cakes! They are SOOOOOO good! :D
author: G C.

description:
Affordable fast Chinese food.
I had two items to go - the atmosphere is not very inviting.
The food was decent but not great compare to B&M on 2nd st.
The salt&pepper fried pork is fatty but has a good taste.
If you have not had it, try it.
author: Ying S.

description:
Eaten and gotten take out a few times at the New Ming's Restaurant and if you think of this as just fast food it might be an okay option if you are careful about your selections.

1st things to avoid.
Chow Fun: There tends to be a 50/50 chance that the Chow Fun they make will be inedible so avoid.
Orange Chicken: More then not this is not the chicken meat rather they have just taken the chicken skins, fried them and covered them in a sweet syrup.

Things they don't tend to mess up.
The Garlic Chicken served on the steam table
 Won Ton Soups ordered off the menu

But everything else is pretty mediocre.

Not a horrible option if you want something really fast and avoid certain dishes, but not a destination place by any stretch of the imagination. If you have options and time there are many other far better places in the 2 - 3 block radius.
author: Joseph A.

description: Best chinese restaurant in SOMA !(maybe?) Authentic Szechuan style! i.e. their spicy food is awesome! And since it's just on the Mission st, Yelpers, check it out!
author: Kevin L.

description: I love their cod fish with broccoli.  Very tasty and seemingly healthy.  I've gone back many times just to get this dish, both for lunch and dinner.   Very casual and I don't go there for the decor or ambience.  I go there for the food and convenient location from where I live in South Beach.  It's also just down the street from the Commonwealth Club and I go frequently as a member.
author: Deborah C.

description: Fast, decent Chinese food, and it's less than a block from the office. I'm still trying to figure out how to order my favorites since the menu on the wall is all English. The wonton noodle soup is not bad, but I'd prefer just about any vegetable to the lettuce floating around in it. The decor and plastic cups remind me of a cafeteria.
author: Wing Y.

description:
I order from Ming's for my office at least once a week. The food is good and the people remember me just by my voice when I call (which makes you feel good no matter where you're at)
The food on the menu and the food you pick out of a line is all pretty good. 
The lady at the register has a sour looking face, but is probably one of the nicest there! 
I totally recommend this place if you're looking for some food Chinese food near the Financial District in SF.
author: Jessica W.

description:
- fast service (very fast)
- cheap and good lunch special deal w/ variety
- so-so food...not great but you get what you pay for
author: Captain B.

description: By far the rudest employees we've encountered in San Francisco. The food was good but their behavior ruined it for us.
author: Jas C.

description:
I came here today with Smoosh for some lunch. We were greeted and given quite a large menu. A few minutes later, we were given another menu listing rice dishes they serve for lunch. I had a secret suspicion it was because Smoosh always eats there and has been getting rice dishes like no one's business. 

I ordered the Dan Dan noodles and Smoosh opted for pork spare ribs and rice. Our orders came out rather quickly. Dan Dan was delicious and spicy (a little too spicy for Smoosh but a mild/medium spicy for me). His pork spare ribs were delicious and the sauce went well with the rice. 

We also got a can on grass jelly. Yum yum yum! I would come back again to try other things (and possibly give it a higher rating).
author: squishy b.

description: Pretty good and reasonably priced.   The hot counter has a pretty good selection.   Stay away from the fried rice.   Yuck!    The Dan Dan Noodle is the bomb!
author: Jerry P.

description:
They have a $10 minimum for credit card purchases (or a $.75 surcharge). 

Hey Ming's- follow the agreement you signed with VISA and maybe I'll be a customer.
author: Antony M.

description: This is a decent Chinese restaurant, but don't just pick food from their counter, order from menu instead. The Sichuan style dishes are very good! The spicy fish filter and spicy fried chicken are the best!
author: Emmy P.

description: It's fast, cheap, simple Chinese food. I come here on occassion for lunch. It may be hard to find a table during lunch hours, but it all clears up at 1:30PM sharp. The lunch special is one, two, or three items with rice or chow mein. Portions are decent. There is free water and tea on the left side of the counter. Get it yourself. There is a $10 minimum for plastic or else pay the $0.75 surcharge (which isn't too bad in my opinion).
author: Jennifer W.

description: I used to frequent the old location with my old cuddy buddies back in the day and it was rather dumpy!  I never liked going there but my crazy friend David loved the fried chicken there.  So fast forward to today my coworkers and I decided we had to eat Chinese food for Gung Hay Fat Choy.  My coworker who is Chinese said it was good luck to eat noodles so we shared chow mien and chow fun, both were very good.  The chicken wings were good too.  This location is a wonderful improvement, clean, new and nicely decorated.  I shall return, I'm curious to find out if they still have that funny pushup chicken.
author: La C.

description:
I really like this place.
Here you will find your typical quick chinese fare.

I always order the 1-Item combo with half steamed rice, half chow mein and then something safe like brocolli beef or orange chicken. The staff is friendly and very efficient.

And you know, while their food might be somewhat unremarkable, their tupperware is rather unbelievable.
author: Richard T.

description:
New Ming's reminds me what an ungrateful little brat I could be as a child.  I ate Chinese food - correction, great chinese food - every single day as a kid.  Rice, steamed fish, cooked vegetables, and soup.  My mom's an amazing cook, and everything always came out tasty and healthy, but I still got really really sick of eating Chinese food and relished every chance I could get to eat like all the other little white kids I went to school with.

Now, as an adult, uh, sorta an adult, I find myself craving stuff like congee, pea shoots, soup noodles, roast duck.  These are my comfort foods, and luckily for me, there's a place right across the street from the office that makes it all.  And they actually understand my Catonese - which is really limited to the vocabulary of a 5-year-old these days - so I can special order stuff like swapping bok choy for lettuce.  

The portions are pretty big, service is fast, I haven't gotten sick, and I haven't gotten too horrible of a MSG headache.  It's not the best Chinese I've had, but they do have the variety and the tastiness that puts their stuff a good notch above just any old Americanized Chinese Cafeteria food.  I do have to say that I would expect this food to cost about $1.50 less anywhere else.
author: Audrey T.

description:
God, I hate wasting money on bad food!  This is what happens when I eat without prior research.  

I walk by this place everyday but have never eaten here before yesterday.   I didn't feel like cooking so I decided to stop in to get some items to go.   Honestly, I didn't expect anything special but the quality of food I took home was absolutely unacceptable.   The hot and sour soup was not hot nor sour - just an inedible, inappropriately sweet, brown mess.  The Mongolian beef resembled no Mongolian beef I've ever had - it's just a stir fry of dry beef with some undercooked veggies and hot sauce.  The salt and pepper calamari was a puffy and greasy mess of dough surrounding chewy and fishy calamari.  I just spent $27 and tossed everything after one bite of each item.    

I hate to be a negative rating lunatic but this is Chinese food at its worst.   I am so pissed that I just stunk up the bus for this crap and now I have to cook dinner.
author: mia s.

description: I am a Chinese food freak and found New Ming's around the corner from the hotel while I was here for a conference.  Wanted something quick to take out, and got the Kung Pao Chicken which was pretty good.  Enjoyed.... but had to pay for ala carte white rice which I never encountered before so that is why they get 4 stars.  Besides that I recommend.
author: Joel K.

description:
Though it's New Ming's, it's really the old Ming's on a different street and a bigger location.  This is probably the least healthy you can get with fast food Chinese, but when you're hungry, you not going to care much. 

Afterwards, you'll be flooded with a sense of guilt. 

The food isn't far better than say Panda Express, but that is not saying very much.  Lots of unnecessary grease and MSG. They're cooking with a hot fire, so I think they can lay off the oil.
author: H L.

description:
This is a place I go to quite frequently... but I think if it was 4 more blocks away, I wouldn't frequent it as much... definitely ones of those places that falls into using the standard CRDDR metric... the Chinese Restaurant Door to Door Ratio... if you have to walk more than a few blocks, it aint worth it

Good  food... good place to go for a quick lunch as its really cheap then... although I wish they still had a meal menu for dinner... everything is a la carte after 2pm... so if you're eating by yourself, be prepared to take home leftovers that you'll probably leave in your fridge for three weeks until the stank reminds you that you shouldnt have bought so much of it in the first place

I've also never seen the ladies behind the counter smile...ever...
Why are they so sad?
author: Ryan K.

description:
We stopped in here before going to the Cartoon Art Museum today.  There's not a lot open on a Saturday in this neighborhood, and this looked cheap and ok.  I checked mobile Yelp, and I saw 3 stars.  Fine.

I got orange chicken, mixed vegetables and fried rice.  The fried rice was really good, the vegetables were vegetables (not much to say here; I do like my cauliflower and broccoli) but it's the orange chicken the ruined the meal.  It had an extremely odd texture that I couldn't place.  I'm thinking maybe that the chicken was rolled around in sand?  Could that be the case?

It was pretty gross.  If I come back here, I'm sticking to the vegetables.
author: Gordon E.

description: The Grand Opening was yesterday and being that it's directly across from the office, Nish and I had to try it. It was relatively decent quick chinese food, with a pretty standard selection, but it was a little too greasy for my taste, they didn't  have plain rice,  and the water tasted a little odd. I have to admit that rarely do I walk into a restaurant and decide I don't want to re-visit, but New Ming's is one of them.  Being as it was the first day open  - I think they're still trying to find their groove. The menu behind the already prepared lunch specials was pretty extensive, but I'm kidding myself if I plan on returning. I'd rather pay a little more for better and less fried chinese food.
author: Jessica T.

description:
It's the Chinese version of the soup nazi ! 

We eat at New Ming's because we are next door and it's cheap, the food is fine, run of the mill Chinese, price is right , whatever, but that is not the story here.

Look out if you want extra soy sauce, and for the love of god prepare to be berated for trying to get more than one (1) hot mustard. This seems to come mostly from the cashier who is absolutely brutal in her conservation of Ming's condiments.

At first I would come back to the office and joke about it the way I was treated saying things like 

"oh, got chewed out again at Ming's they thought I wanted two items but I only wanted one" 

or 

"so weird, I asked for extra soy but she didn't give it to me ???"

But as it began to happen to other co-workers we noticed a pattern. 

Your first thought is: OH maybe it's a language barrier but nice try, I speak a little Cantonese so that ain't it ! English or Chinese the service is the same, order your items, pay for your food, do not ask for anything extra, and get the hell out !

So today one of the guys on the desk went over to pick up food for 3 of us, I told him going in we were gonna need a lot of hot mustard (a relative term) and to expect a fight, well he got one.  

After purchasing 3 separate entrees he asked for extra hot mustard, one of the girls behind the counter was about to give it to him but here comes the fried rice nazi, yelling at the girl, and then turning to my co-worker to yell at him to explain why he needed so much !? 

"So much" in this case was a total of 6 packets, or 2 per entree.

Fortunately he is an ex-Naval officer he was ready for her, he fired back "NO MUSTARD NO FOOD ORDER!" and won the day, but that didn't stop her from tearing into some poor construction worker who asked for an extra soy sauce.

Do I think this is bad service ? Well yeah, sort of, but more than that I think it's funny. So please, go eat there, and when you do BE SURE to ask for more condiments, then stand back and cover your ears because it's gonna be fire in the hole !

Average food, good prices, and hysterically hostile service, only in S.F.
author: red c.

description:
I use to go to the old ming's a lot more often because it's a tad bit closer to me. They have pretty good prices for lunch and a variety of food to order off the menu. I suggest you call in your order so you don't have to wait in line. 

Ever since they moved to this new location, the food just didn't taste the same to me. Occasionally I'll still swing by to pick up 1 items or 2 item lunch with chow mein or fried rice.  You have to show up before 2pm here because they won't have anymore fresh food to pick from!
author: Nancy L.

description: Good deal for take out or a quick lunch and dinner. The prices are very affordable and the food are tasty.
author: T B.

description:
I really wanted some chow mein to bring to a potluck party and just didn't have the time or energy to walk over to Chinatown and get my order in there.  In comes New Ming's, which was just a 5 minute walk away from work.  I was a little hesitant to try the place because there is honestly no ambiance to speak of- just a steam table at the back of the restaurant and tables and chairs filled with hungry people eating gigantic mounds of food.  Though the prepared items did look tasty, I stuck to my original craving and got two orders of the chicken with cabbage chow mein.

They were able to whip up those two orders in record time- I was probably in and out in 5 minutes.  The total cost was $12 and there was more than enough chow mein to float a boat.
