The chow mein was a little too soft for my taste, but the seasoning wasn't bad.  The chicken was tender and the cabbage was fairly fresh so overall, it made for some good eats.

I'd be back to try the combination plates at lunch, which are very fairly priced at $3.95 for one item or $4.95 for two items.  I think thats cheaper than what you would pay at Panda Express over at the Westfield Mall.  Their regular menu also seems pretty extensive- they have seven types of porridge, as well as udon noodle soups and sizzling platters, all of which sound really appealing during these cold winter months.  Now if only they could liven up the place and make it a little cheerier...
author: Angela H.

description: It's open for late night dinners. The clay pots are really awesome. Can't go wrong with the fried chicken and my brother always enjoys the walnut prawns dish. The price is really reasonable and the waitresses are really nice. Awesome food and friendly service.
author: Desmond N.

description:
Lunch is great here! They are fast friendly and the food is pretty damn decent!  Even to the standards of my fellow co-worker that has been homesick since coming here from Hong Kong 3 months ago. 
One of the lil ladies that works there (the one that speaks English.......broken but she does) Sees me with a list and doesn't even  need to look at it! She already knows who orders what. She tells me the "american boy with long hair orders Orange Chicken w/ steam rice, he no like fried rice" and the tall indian boy will not eat beef" LMAO!! That is awesome! How does she remember that? 

Without fail my orders from her are always perfect. And prepared quickly.
The best $5.00 you can spend for lunch if you're looking for fast Chinese!
author: Anna P.

description:
My friend introduced this place to me.  Cheap, fast, to-go box packed full.  Rice noodles with shrimp.  Lots of egg in it, just the way I love it.
Call ahead and just pick up your order during the busy lunch rush.

Sometimes you just want a notch better than the fast food "Chinese" at the mall.
author: Denise M.

description:
The place is clean and definitely gets busy during lunch hour which I consider to be a good sign. Service is good and fast. Generous portion size for the price - excellent value!  

This is your very typical "mmm, I feel like some Chinese" type of place that takes you from "hallooow, fo here o to go?" to "$6.50 please" to "Thank you for coming..." in under 15 minutes.

My only suggestion for improvement would be to convert the tables that seat 4 people to 2 tables that seat 2 each. Too often I see just one person taking up the entire table and people that are uncomfortable sharing a table are forced to walk down and eat in the downstairs dungeon.
author: Kirill N.

description:
I've worked across the street from this place for nearly a year, and it's a travesty that I've eaten here all of two times in over 10 months.  

My co-worker calls this sort of restaurant "steam tray restaurant" as they cook up the food in the back and serve it out of heated trays in the front (think Panda Express).

Two item combo with rice or chow mein noodles is $4.95 and if you make sure you pick food that is fresh from the kitchen (and hasn't sat too long in the steam trays), you up your odds of getting something good.

Last time I had sesame chicken which was hot and savory, with string beans which were crunchy and flavorful.  The chow mein was sort of soft, so next time I'll try the rice.

So if you love a hot plate of low-brow Chinese food for lunch from time to time, New Mings is worth checking out.
author: Brad P.

description:
Plus: It's right across the street from our office, and it just opened, the staff was pretty friendly (maybe being opening day)

Minus: It's nothing too special, I've had better fast food Chinese from a lot of places, this just happens to be convenient

Reality: It's great for a quick, no hassle lunch, and the space is clean, so if anything I'll being going back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Nish N.

description: This place is a solid cheap-chinese lunch spot. They have a great steam table of ready-to-eat food, as well as a great menu that you can order off too. They even have morning breakfast items like jook. The wonton soup sounds good, I'll have to try it one day.
author: grant l.

description: decent Chinese food in the SOMA area. They are definitely efficient in getting people in and out of the door during a lunch rush, which i appreciate. Prices are reasonable, and the quality of food is pretty good, much better than B&M around the corner.  But take my warning, if you want something that is made to order, be prepared to wait at least 15-20 minutes.  (sometimes longer).
author: Peter C.

description:
There's much controversy over the quality of New Ming's and all through the office run words of hearsay.  But when I listen to my heart, and I have to be still in the cacophony of this neighborhood, be still I whisper, and listen to the words that my heart speaks on behalf of my stomach below.  I understand not that rumbling tongue, but what I do understand is one word rising up from my chest, filling my lungs.  That one sweet word: Delicious.

I won't go out on a limb and say this is damn the most awesome food you're gonna get this side of the Great Wall, but like Wendy said, if it's raining or if you want some comfort food, they why the hell not?  After all, for what you're paying over there, you can't ask for much, but you get a hell of a lot.

Oh, and by the way, I was very wary of the place until we had one of those "Fuck it" moments.  It was all Ming's after that.  

Ming the Conquerer was stronger than iron.  
Ming the Conquerer was softer than silk.
Ming the Conquerer has felled another.  
Ming the Conquerer is gentler still.
author: Roy M.

description: Seriously, I don't even want to give this place a star. UGH.  It was so BAD! My boyfriend and I went up to the Bay for New Year's and it was New Year's Eve and we found this place before going to MOMA.  We were both hungry and decided let's just eat here.  What a mistake! First off the food was BLAND.  I had the orange chicken and some tofu dish.  Okay, really how can you fail tofu? Well, this place it did - it was BLAND! The orange chicken didn't taste like orange or chicken for that matter, This place was horrible.  We should have eaten at the museum cafe.  Now we know for next time.  But really - don't go here!
author: Kristine W.

description:
First day at a new job, & down the block is MING'S restaurant. Being one filthy minger in a group of many, how could I NOT have my first lunch there?

By the way, the word "minger" is British slang for a filthy, ugly & generally undesirable person. Thanks to my dear friend Rebecca for introducing me to that word several years ago. And our loosely-knit group of neighborhood friends is known as the Western Addition Mingers Association, or WAMA. Though some of us have moved into different neighborhoods or out of the city altogether, we are all still mingers, & we all still rep WAMA.

Anyway, as is to be expected of a place called "Ming's", it was a litlte bit minging (I guess one could never accuse them of false advertising, eh?). I wouldn't recommend the fried rice, the sesame chicken or the beef & broccoli. All were just alright (maybe even sub-par). I also found it to be a little bit expensive, but then again, this was my first lunch as a dude working in the FiDi. Ming's may very well be one of the cheapest lunches in the entire 'hood for all I know.

I wouldn't say I won't eat lunch there again. I just don't expect it to ever become a lunchtime mainstay for my as-of-yet unestablished routine.
author: Pete J.

description: This is the go to spot for porridge! You get a huge bowl and it is very tasty and delicious. To be honest, my rating for this place is mainly for the porridge. I would walk up the street to B&M for some other menu items, but this place is not bad at all.
author: Adrian P.

description:
I keep coming here because a whole bunch of peeps from work come here and I tag along.  

I admit, their garlic chicken is mighty tasty, and the prices are the best in this area.  But I eat here more because I need to stave off hunger pains than to experience world-class Chinese cuisine.  Which is what you need sometimes, just to quell hunger and not resort to bread and water.

ETA: Man, I keep being asked to write more!  Okay, here it goes...

I'm not knocking the decor or service with my 2 star rating.  It's seems like a pleasant place to have lunch during the day, even though I've only done take out.  The employees are always kind yet brisk in their service.  You probably can't find a better place to get quick, cheap Chinese food in the area.

I'm just never, ever inspired enough by what I've eaten here to go on my own.  The food is just...fine. And going by the Yelp rating system, I am totally Meh on this place AND I've experienced better.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
I find this this place to be a good , fast , and reliable lunch spot. The ladies that work the counter are always friendly and they really keep the line moving! I have ordered both from the pre made stuff and off the menu and have enjoyed both. The prices are excellent and the portions size is good. 
$4.95 for a two item combo.
author: Lisa A.

description:
It was just one of those days where I needed to get a fix of fast Chinese food, and Mings really delivered!!

Got a two item to-go with orange chicken, salt and pepper pork chop, and fried rice... KILLED IT.  

Both the pork chop and orange chicken were DEEEE-lish. 
Minute critique: Orange chicken was a little bit on the firmer side, and the fried rice was a tad off.

Like the new cleaner location vs. their location on 2nd, near market.
author: shaun l.

description: I forgot how good cheap greasy Chinese food from New Mings can be. This 2011 healthy eating has deprived me of some of the good things in life. Imma have to skip the Specialty cookies and splurge on this every month or so. Why do I ever go to B&M??
author: Kiristen R.

description:
I do have to disabuse some of the upbraiding comments made by previous reviewers:

1) The staff is NOT rude. I've been in the Bay Area long enough to know what bad customer service means... and this is not it. Just don't expect chatty, peppy servers that drool all over you for the extra tip. This is a fast food restaurant in SOMA! 

2) The food isn't bad. It's just fast food. Much like you wouldn't reasonably expect a fine-dining experience from Burger King, this is simply filler Chinese food.

3) Illegal practices is a bit of a stretch. There's a hand-written sign on the cashier-machine that requests a $10 minimum -- and this is very frequent all over California, be it legal or not. However, when my to-go box only racked up $8.50 and I flashed my card with an apologetic look, they swiped me without any extra charges and I was happily on my way.

I've come here a couple of times and, to be honest, I always see your typical suited professional waltz in here with haute airs... and be rightly treated with the same dismissal that s/he offers. As anywhere else, a good attitude is half the trick. Beyond that, it's fast food, it's cheap, it's satiating, and it may have some MSG... But really: it's just bloody lunch!
author: G. J.

description: New Ming, you haven't changed a bit.  Still just basic Chinese food with a little something up on Panda Express...sometimes.  Basically it's okay if you are looking for Chinese food and if you are bored of everything else around it.
author: Luke M.

description:
Disgusting. 

That's really all I need to say but I will add a bit about my experiences. The staff is extremely rude, if you ask for any change on the menu they wont do it. Not only that they will even tell you they don't want your business and ask you to leave. The food is really bad, it's full of MSG and preservatives. I ate with 8 people from my office and all of us agreed we would NEVER go back as the food and service are among the worst restaurant experiences I have ever had.

Furthermore, like the other reviewer, they charge you more if you use a credit card. In the state of CA it's illegal to impose a minimum credit card amount on consumers. 

STAY AWAY:

* RUDE STAFF

* BAD FOOD

* ILLEGAL BUSINESS PRACTICES
author: D. X.

description:
Cheap and Fast - Its great for lunch. it's alot cleaner than the old Mings. Stay away from the ready made items on the counter. I usually order from the menu. It's quick and fresh. Try the deep fried flounder (w/ rice). For $6.95 this is a bargain and it's huge! usually at other places this goes $12 easy.  

quick tip their menu on the wall is different from their takeout menu. Don't miss out on stuff and look at both.
author: Louie C.

description:
Nothing special here, simply put: cheap Chinese food.

I got the half fried rice and half noodle meal. Boy was this combo filled with grease or what?  I should've known better when I first walked in here and smelled the grease/MSG in the air.  If my nose wasn't working, my sense of touch was the next signal.  The floors were stick, the tables were sticky, everything about this place was sticky, even the food!
author: Elliot Y.

description: Eww. Vinegar anyone? After reading the reviews i was expecting standard  Chinese food. Yum. Instead what I received was soaked in vinegar and barley edible. We started out with pot stickers. the skins were way to thick but might have been OK if they included a dipping sauce other then vinegar. Seriously, plain vinegar. For entrees we shared a sesame beef and a spicy/chicken/ eggplant thing. Yuck. White rice doesn't come with it. Maybe that's a San Fran thing.Sesame beef was perfectly crispy but lacking sesame seeds. I mean there was not a single one. The worst offense was the the sauce of ketchup and vinegar. So sour and that was the good dish. The other one was like a Romen packet thickened with corn starch and a cup of salt. It was literally inedible. The waitress asked no questions as she took a full plate of food to the garbage. Eww. Vinegar. Eww. Do not eat here. It is so bad. I am hoping that there food is actually good but they were just fucking with white by feeding us lots of vinegar. Otherwise they taste it how can they not know?
author: Corey Jace W.

description: Very good, moderately cheap Chinese food (their dishes have that HEAT if you know what I mean!) Chinese is my comfort food and I'm very comfortable here!
author: Robin H.

description:
Very friendly cafeteria-style service. I love that their menu on the wall, under Wonton Soups, says "choice: wonton noodle or wonton noodle."

The joint was jumping when I got there -- almost every table was occupied. Service was fast and friendly, and I liked that they had tapioca and milk teas (but what is "milk tea with coffee?" It sounds dangerous).

I got the duck wonton soup, a generous portion with duck meat on the bone for $6. The soup was tasty, and the wontons and duck meat were good, but the base was a little oily. Then again, duck isn't the leanest of meats. I'd have liked it if the meat were not on the bone -- it was a little like trying to eat a rib dish, with the added complication of the little riblets being submerged in broth. There was no dainty way around it.

New Ming's won't replace B&M for me, where I can get a huge bowl of hot and sour soup for cheap, nor is it a Henry's Hunan killer, but it's nice to have the variety in the neighborhood. Next time, I'll go with a non-duck soup.
author: Pat T.

description:
Below average.  I had two different "spicy" (Umm, not at all) chicken dishes with steamed rice.  Yes, it was cheap.   Ok, you need to understand one thing about me and ordering chopped-up chicken dishes... I inspect the chicken like a frickin nazi.  any hint of stringy, cartilage-y, fatty, bone-y or otherwise undesirable-y thing joining two otherwise decent bites of chicken and it's off my plate faster than you can poke it with a stick.   (I try not to order much chicken when I'm eating out, but I didn't see any beef dishes and I won't go the tofu route) So, with my two chicken dishes, I ended up with at least one complete "dish" in the Hell No Pile.   So much for cheap when you can't eat like half of it.
As for taste - there wasn't much.
author: Meg W.

description: If you love minimums on credit card purchases, watered down sauces, soggy flavorless tofu, bland dry rice, small portions and an overall cold and pointless meal....this is your spot.
author: Mack D.

description:
Their food is very good. Ingredients are fresh, vegetables are NEVER overcooked, service is fast, portions are large, and the prices are very reasonable especially  for this neighborhood.

If you have one of their menus and you're ordering a rice plate on the phone, make sure you specify that you want it over rice. One time, I did not specify it and I was wondering why it was so much more expensive than on the menu. It turns out they thought I didn't want the rice.

For instance, if you want the broccoli chicken rice plate, say  "broccoli chicken rice plate." Otherwise, you will get just broccoli chicken and the price will be a few dollars more. Then again, that might be what you want.

During lunch, you can either order off the menu or order items  from their hot food counter.

Personally, I prefer ordering off the menu. 

I've tried their broccoli chicken, rock cod fish in black bean sauce with bok choy, and barbeque pork chow mein. All of it was very good.

Their fried rice, however, is only average.

Another reason I like them is they're open late and on Saturday.
author: Wendy L.

description:
This place is pretty good, and satisfied my craving for chinese today.  It's light years better than Panda Express.  If Panda were Earth, then New Ming's would be NGC-1417.  For those of you who don't know what/where that is, if one of the planets in that galaxy had a high powered telescope, and pointed it at Earth, they would see Dinosaurs.  Dinosaurs.

Anyhow, I was initially skeptical since it's a SOMA Chinese restaurant, however, I was somewhat relieved once I arrived and saw some Chinese patrons.  I had 2 item combo which included chow mein, garlic chicken and salty pork.  Yum!  The meat was on par with other Chinese places (non-chain) I've been to, and the mein was aiite.  They do except credit cards for orders over $10.  I went around 12:30pm for lunch, and there was a line, but it went quickly.  There was still seating available.

Overall, the place was good and I'd go back since it's fairly close to work.
author: Casey F.

description:
I've been trying to find some decent Chinese food near my office and NMR has become a decent if not spectacular option. The restaurant itself is spacious and usually comfortably filled with the lunch and convention crowd.

The wait staff and cashier are so-so, I've found myself not barking back at some curt server when trying to pay for my lunch. 

The prices are decent although I'm used to more for my money (despite the number of items in your combo, they always seem to use the same sized plate). The items that I've sampled (sesame chicken, pepper pork, sweet and sour) have been good-- but for some reason I'm always left a little on the hungry side. Guess I'll have to upgrade to the three item combo. The self serve free tea/hot water station is a nice touch.
author: Gil L.

description:
I'd should've went to B & M on 2nd St... I just forgot where it was. 

On the food, the chow mein was in dire need of soy sauce or just more flavor; a cardinal sin for a Chinese restaurant in my book. Broccoli beef was acceptable, but still could'a used some more flavor. 

I was also disappointed they ran outta many of their dishes at 2:30pm and made no apparent effort to replace them. No pork to be found anywhere outta umpteen dishes, another cardinal sin for a Chinese restaurant. 

Check the CHEAP box for N. Ming's. Cheap, but I'd rather pay for flavor, Got outta there for 5 bucks, the one item and chow mein.
author: tim y.

description:
I ate here once and I did not like this place.

The women who work here are friendly and fast on their feet.

If you're eating here, the wait for your food takes forever. Not good when I only had 30 minutes for lunch.

The food was NOT good. Nor was my tapioca drink. The tapioca balls were hard. The drink was gross tasting. I have never had a bad tapioca drink before until coming here.

Discovered this little gem by accident. Great service and great food!

UPDATE: So I went to this place again with my friend that lives in the city. We ordered the hot and sour soup and it was so spicy!! The waitress said "You should have told us you didn't want it that spicy." I said "Last time we came here it wasn't that spicy!!" and she wouldn't exchange it or give us a refund for it. Both me and my friend could not eat it at all. Lowering my rating from 5 stars to 3 for horrible service. Besides the soup I still like the food here. Worth a drive from San Jose to the city to take my friend from the city again? Absolutely not.
author: Dan M.

description:
New Ming's contributes to every minute of my day.  You see, my office window faces New Ming's, and I get to see every bloke who walks in.  Still, it took me a couple weeks of watching Mission St before I decided to try their food.  I used to go to the old Ming's a couple blocks away, and they have pretty much the same food here though a bit more variety.  This place is a mix between B&M's and the old Ming's - not exactly a hole in the wall, but not a medium size restaurant.  Yes, it is still pretty cheap, and they do take credit cards (yay!).  Good greasy comfort food.

I personally don't worry too much about food quality/cleanliness as everything seems pretty well cooked, but once upon a time in the old Ming's, I saw them chop some broccoli and accidentally drop them on the floor and then pick up those bits and put them back in the pot.  Hah.
author: Connie L.

description: Awesome..why? I know it's not the best Chinese food, but that's not what I was expecting. I expected buffet-style-mall-type-food since the prices were relatively low- and that's almost just what I got, except you could order fantastic drinks on the side. I got absolutely delightful hot jasmine tea. This place is a perfect spot for a quick work lunch.
author: Wanjiru K.

description: I usually come here whenever I'm craving chinese food for lunch. I love how cheap the food is & the quality of food is pretty decent for the price. I rather eat here than go to Yank Sing 2 Go.
author: Krystel M.

description: Decidedly average, but decent enough for a quick Chinese lunch. The sesame chicken & orange chicken are okay. I also had the fried tofu and green bean dish once and found it to be a bit lacking taste-wise. The service is fast, and the price is good, at least for their lunch specials. It's Panda Express-level Chinese, but sometimes that does the trick when you're not feeling particularly discerning.
author: Jon S.

description:
For me New Ming's lunch is a once a week affair. I've learned a few things. Here's what to look out for:

1. Get there before 2:30 or else it's slim pickens.
2. The salt and pepper pork is the best hot lamp dish.
3. Ask for take out even if you plan on eating in because you get more food and you get to rock the awesome tupperware.
4. If you order a 2 item combo eat the orange chicken first.

I come here often but, truly, the food is standard chinese fare. I would give this place 3 stars but, Damn! That tupperware is so fine.
author: Rodney V.

description: They have boba drinks here! I was walking by this place and saw their decently priced menu for lunch and that they had boba drinks so I decided to check it out.  Food is decent and the boba is good, staff seems very friendly and fast!  I wouldn't go here for authentic Chinese but its great for a cheap and fast lunch.  I had a lunch combo plate of green beans, garlic chicken, and chow mein and will definitely return to try more items!
author: Tracy N.

description: I ordered the Singapore noodle and experienced a rapid heart rate after eating it. I think it was the MSG. Avoid this place if you have high-blood pressure issues.
author: A B.

description:
$6.10 for a fried rice and two sides combo -- which means I come here way too often for some comfort Chinese food.

But you gotta get here before 1:30 otherwise there won't be any food left to choose from and you'll be stuck with lukewarm food.

1 star for great service -- super fast and polite (they apologized about 10 times while I stood there waiting for them to cook more 'mixed vegetables.')
1 star for great tasting comfort food (even though there is probably too much oil and MSG for my heart).
1 star for not burning a hole through my wallet.
1 star for being in such a convenient location!
author: Jon H.

description: Solid lunch place to go to.  The sesame chicken is good - it's my go to.  The noodles are a bit greasy, and I try to avoid fried rice normally so I go for the steamed rice.  In and out, quick and simple.
author: Kym P.

description: Outstanding! Had the Hot & Sour soup and Cashew Chicken. very tasty.
author: Alan Y.

description:
decent chinese downtown. plus they're open late which is a plus when working nights. 

i recommend: veggie chowfun, westlake beef soup, the hong kong style scrambled eggs with shrimp over chow fun and the potstickers are pretty yum. 

i've pretty much got the whole office hooked. sooo hip hip go mings!
author: chanchan c.

description: Order from the menu for the freshest selection. The salt & pepper tofu is amazing. Softly crispy on the outside and juicy and hot on the inside. Many other vegetarian dishes also available. Decor is cheap, but the staff is always friendly.
author: Brian F.

description: So after yesterday's Y.E.S. festivities it was absolutely necessary that I slurp a nourishing, warm bowl of broth, not stew, but broth, easier on the tummy. Got my soup, smelled delish. My Advil supressed headache became instantly better with the thought of sustenance. I stirred it around a bit and dove in. I choked five bites later as I saw a delightful RING OF APHIDS on the rim of my bowl.
author: Ligaya T.

description: I guess there were too many ladies working behind the counter at the old Ming's so they decided to open up this one. We recognized some of the same workers at this new location. The old Ming's is just a block up and over. New Ming's is obviously nicer and cleaner than the old one. The menu is pretty much the same, but items are about $1 more. There's a lot more seating and they do take credit cards, so they have that advantage.
author: Connie C.

description: I can't believe I haven't been here before.  It's cheap, close, and chinese.  Love the lunch combo.  I'll be going here for the next 2 weeks and getting something different everyday.  AND always for under 6 bucks.   Lets say i want fried rice, tofu & green beans, and sesame chicken.  That'll come to $5.40 inc. tax.  By the way, all that filled me up plenty.
author: John B.

description: Pretty decent Chinese place here. It's more of a sit-down restaurant than a fast food joint, a notch above a hole in the wall Chinese take out joint. They offer lots of variety at good prices. I got spinach and rice to go - I guess it's hard to mess that up.
author: Laurie c.

description: This is probably the best Chinese restaurant in Idaho! Oh...this is San Francisco? Never mind.
author: Johnny O.

description: Meh... Tried New Ming's on the way to a Giants game the other night. We were kind of in a hurry to get to the game, and the lady who took our order assured us that they were "really fast." 20 minutes later we got our food- sesame beef and braised tofu and eggplant with szechuan sauce. It wasn't terrible but it was pretty generic, and definitely not worth waiting 20 minutes for. I thought the sesame beef was gross... Definitely wouldn't order the beef here again. The tofu eggplant thing was edible, but not good enough to recommend this place. I *might* give New Ming's another shot for a lunch special or something, but based on my first experience I would describe it as exceedingly mediocre, not so fast Chinese fast food.
author: Brian H.

description: I can't really say anything bad about New Ming's, nor can I say anything really bad about them. The food is average for quick fix chinese food, the service is super fast and it's close to work for me. Not really worth saying much else. If you are craving chinese food and don't have to go far to get here, it's a decent place to get it. If you have to travel to get there, I wouldn't bother.
author: Jason B.

description: It's quick and cheap. Typical standard Chinese fast food. Portion is just right and you can't ask for more for that price in downtown SF.
author: Julie T.

description: Just like Panda Express, except without all those pesky teenagers hanging about.
author: Michael E.

description: I really wanted to like this place, as it sat depressingly empty right across the street from my office, seemingly starring forlornly up at me through my window.  But while I wouldn't necessarily judge the quality of a Chinese restaurant by it's general's chicken, I do have to take exception with a place where I don't even want to finish eating my meal on a hungry stomach, so alas it was not to be.
author: Nick B.

description: The folks I'm working with now really like the grab-and-go lunch so we hit up this place. I was in an out with a two-item combo for $6 in just a few minutes. They definitely don't hold back on the portions. I had to skip dinner because I was still so full. The food is decent.
author: Barney M.

description: the food are like Panda express . It's good for nearby office people to come for lunch. but need to pay extra$0.75 if you use credit card to pay for amount under $10.
author: Ying X.

description:
I dropped in here on Friday for lunch and was pleased with the food. I was craving Chinese food and the line at Panda Express at the mall was out the door, so I figured I'd give this place a shot as its across the street from work. They have some awesome combo specials (advertisement out front with prices), and I ended up getting the 2 item combo with chow mein, orange chicken, and kung pao chicken. My total meal came out to $6.00  (did not order a drink), which was awesome for the amount of food they gave me.

I thought the chow mein was better than Panda's and the kung pao chicken was pretty good.. The orange chicken was not as tangy as Panda's (which I like more), but it was still tasty. For the most part this place has decent, fast, and cheap Chinese food. Note: I took my order to go, but they have plenty of seats inside to sit at if you're eating there.
author: Jon W.

description: Where the hell is the good Chinese food in this town?  I swear to god, I have been to a million places and I am always left feeling so un-satisfied.  Yes, it is cheap, downtown and close to my office, not an excuse.  The tofu and green beans is okay, but it buck stops here.  Must I only have the option to have fried food or have it be covered in sweet gooey sauce?  Ahhhh, someone please tell me where I can find deliciousness as this is not the place.
author: Nicole F.

description: Very dependable, tastey food right by school, not stellar, but definitely passable.  I walked in when I realised I had arrived in SoMa way too early for my meeting so popped in here for a quick bite.  Nice clean interior, hot tea to drink and cheap prices.  I'd go again.
author: Asha H.

description: Good food thats flavorful most likely because they use MSG. A good place to substitute Panda express WITH the MSG.
author: Keoni U.

description:
i freaking love this place. and since it's right across the street from yelp headquarters, i'm not surprised it has a buncha reviews. 

it is my favorite place for "quick and dirty" chinese. and i feel remiss that i haven't yelped this spot yet, because it's my secret favorite lunch option, as i work right down the street on new montgomery.

speaking of secrets, i secretly admire those who actually order off the menu. i've only ordered from the pre-made food buffet. i recommend the garlic chicken - little balls of garlicky fried chicken. god, they are so good, they are my achilles heel. also, of course get string beans. because string beans + soy sauce a happy couple maketh.  they pile the plates high for you, and they're under $6. done and done.
author: Marla W.

description: Mings is what it is. Its not high end chinese food. However, its very solid. If you are in the hood you are craving chinese, I think this is the best place in the neighborhood. I like it much more then Henrys Hunan.
author: Alden H.

description: I ordered food here for a work meeting and was very pleased.  Their menu is nice and varied.  Prices are very reasonable and the location is great (right next to my building).  I especially enjoyed the braised tofu and eggplant dish.
author: Rebecca G.

description: I have tried this restaurant a few times and each of the dishes I have had have been watery.  The chicken dishes tend to be more chicken fat and tendons than actual meat.  Would not be my first choice for the area.
author: Amit P.

description: This place is good if you don't feel like cooking and just want to get something for to go.  I don't think the food here is that greasy and they have updated their menu since they opened.  Every time I walk by during lunch it's always packed!
author: JenJen W.

description: Really good food for cheap.  I never had a problem with the girl's there have been nice to me since it has been open.  Not a place where you would hang out for about a hour but eat your food and go.  I especially like the Black peppered beef extra spicy.
author: mike p.

description: i love this place!  their chinese food quality is pretty good and so affordable.  if you're in need of a quickie, lunch that is, new ming's is best choice.  they offer a good selection of ready to mix and match food and for 2 items and rice or noodles, it's only $6.10 out the door.  but if you don't happen to have cash on hand, they have some good selections on the menu which takes less than 10 mins to fulfill the $10 minimum credit card charge.  i suggest shrimp fried rice...enough to eat half today and the other for another day.
author: Marjie T.

description: I usually ordering garlic chicken and ma po tofu over rice and it's spicy and delicious. Plus, you get enough for 2 meals for a $6 lunch combo! I give it 4 stars because it's unpretentious and succeeds at what it sets out to do, which isn't to create gourmet masterpieces, but just to serve solid, fresh food.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I don't know - I went here on a referral from a co-worker.  I didn't see what the rave was about after my first visit, I thought the food was bland.  BUT I went back a few weeks later and, well I guess I'm a little embarrassed to say I really like it.  :P  I think the old chef came back.  I'm sorry to say I never went to the Old Ming's but for a full plate of food at a decent price, not bad!  

It's just chinese, not Gone With the Wind.
author: joy j.

description: It's like the housing thread, I'm scared yet somehow attracted to eating here. The place is clean enough, but I've never seen more than one or two people inside. Granted it's not during lunch rush, but still. Since there's not much else open for dinner during the week or on Saturdays, you'd think they'd get more traffic. Other reviews didn't really help things either. But, mostly because I'm lazy and there isn't much else really close by that's open when I'm hungry, I grab takeout here fairly often. You're probably better off getting the plates versus a full order. The full orders are pretty big. The rice plates are half the price and you get a good sized meal. I've had the usual assortment of dishes, nothing spectacular and nothing horrible. Haven't had the noodles or porridge, so can't comment. Though I've seen others slurp it up so must not be too bad. Anyway, in a land where nothing is open, NMR is a decent option.
author: The Sock S.

description: when i first started my job, my new co-workers highly recommended ming's for lunch. i'm really picky when it comes to chinese food so i was a little skeptical. but since the co-workers happened to be chinese, well, hey, ming's must be pretty good, right? WRONG. SO WRONG. i finally caved and got the chow mein. how is it possible to make such greasy, flavorless noodles? don't even look to the packet of crappy soy sauce for some glimmer of hope. what they call soy sauce is just dark brown water. i don't get the appeal. yeah, it's cheap, but the money you save on food, you'll end up spending on maalox.
author: Adrienne Y.

description: This place is a great stop for lunch! It's super quick and inexpensive and pretty tasty for quick Chinese food, which is hard to find downtown. I always order my own noodles and each time they are great.
author: Michelle D.

description: the deep fried chicken wings here are delicious!  but then again, almost anything deep fried is delicious. :)
author: Pickle R.

description: i've been dying to find a place that has good fried chicken wings.  the ones without all the flower and heaviness and extra crispy.  they do it here.  pretty cheap too.  sweet and sour pork chop is tasty too.  the menu also has some szechuan and taiwanese cold dishes.  will try next time.  they even have porridge until 10pm.  can't complain for the price and convenience.
author: Food Is L.

description:
i got a 3-item combo: beef broccoli, black pepper pork, and mandarin chicken with chow mein. the pork and chow mein were ok, but the other 2 were pretty bland. i liked the place on kearny & sutter better.

i've heard that the menu items are better, but i haven't tried them yet.
author: AJ C.

description: i was shocked on saturday night when i walked into this place.  first, it was open.  most places are closed in downtown during the weekend.  second, they were polite.  i find that to be a change since most of the china town restaurants only want to sell to chinese people.  thrid, they are affordable.  i got fried rice and lamb curry.  the fried rice was perfect and had little pieces of shrimp in there.  it tasted just like the way my mother used to make it.  the lamb was fantastic with just enough spices.  it also had hot peppers in there which added a nice flavor.  it was excellent and the price came to $20.  the portions were huge too.  i couldn't believe how much food they gave me.  the appearance of the place might throw off some people.  it looks like chinese fast food.  in fact it is set up to be fast food like.  however, the food is top notch and i plan on trying more dishes there in the near future.  lastly, they were quick.  my food came out in a few minutes and the cook hand delivered it to me.  i found my new chinese restaurant in downtown.
author: T D.

description: I too frequented this restaurant on occasion. Their hot table fare is fast and good as well as well priced. Frankly, I'm usually in a rush so I've never tried anything specifically made for me from their kitchen. The place is very clean as well. But as another Yelper noted they insist on a minimum of $10 if using a  Visa or MC . This is clearly not acceptable and not allowed in their contract with either of these credit card companies. I discovered this one afternoon when I was in and I whipped out my MC  and the lady rang up $10 on my $7.00 order. It never entered my mind as there is a credit card symbol prominently displayed on the front door.  When I questioned this she pointed to a hand written little sign near the cash register. I mean they didn't even say a word . I protested stating that this was not permitted but the Asian lady smiled and pointed to the refrigerator and told me to get some drinks. Perhaps the owners of Ming's will realize that they're losing out on a significant amount of lunchtime business.  If not, then avoid this place.
author: Nick C.
